       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="ENGR-AD 343">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=ENGR-AD%20343">
          ENGR-AD 343 Foundation Engineering Design
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course introduces the development of foundation engineering, including site exploration, soil sampling, interpretation of boring logs, bearing capacity of footings, settlement of structures, lateral earth pressure. Design of retaining walls, design of braced excavations and sheet pile walls; and design of deep foundations are covered.
          </p>
          <p>
           2 credits
          </p>
         </div>
         <p class="discussion">
          This course has a
          <strong>
           discussion section
          </strong>
          .
         </p>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="146">
            Civil Engineering
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="prerequisites">
          <li>
           Geotechnical Engineering
          </li>
         </ul>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="ENGR-AD 344">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=ENGR-AD%20344">
          ENGR-AD 344 Transportation and Traffic Engineering
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course introduces the different modes of transportation and their characteristics with emphasis on road users, vehicles, highways and control devices and their impact on traffic operations. It also introduces the quantification of traffic stream characteristics and the design and use of traffic control devices, including a detailed treatment of traffic signal timing and design for both pre-timed and actuated signals. Coordination of signal systems on arterials and in networks is covered. A broad overview of highway traffic safety issues, policies, programs, and mitigation measures are included.
          </p>
         </div>
         <p class="discussion">
          This course has a
          <strong>
           discussion section
          </strong>
          .
         </p>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2014
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <span class="schedule">
             MW, 2:15-3:30 pm (Sem)
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2014
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <span class="schedule">
             W, 3:30-6:00 pm (Lab)
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2 2015
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            7 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/mohamad-talas.html">

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="ENGR-AD 345">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=ENGR-AD%20345">
          ENGR-AD 345 Design of Traffic Systems
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course provides an introduction to design of traffic systems with emphasis on highway design. Students are introduced to the basic design concepts of horizontal and vertical alignment, super elevation, and cross-section design. The course also covers fundamentals of intersection and interchange design, pavement design, design of parking facilities, as well as bikeway and walkway design.
          </p>
          <p>
           2 credits
          </p>
         </div>
         <p class="discussion">
          This course has a
          <strong>
           discussion section
          </strong>
          .
         </p>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="146">
            Civil Engineering
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="prerequisites">
          <li>
           Transportation and Traffic Engineering
          </li>
         </ul>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="ENGR-AD 346">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=ENGR-AD%20346">
          ENGR-AD 346 Water Resources Engineering
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course provides a detailed overview of water resources engineering, including both analysis and design elements. Topics covered: open-channel flow; pipe networks; reservoir balances; hydrologic techniques; surface water and ground-water supplies; water demand; and development of water resources for multiple purposes.
          </p>
          <p>
          </p>
         </div>
         <p class="discussion">
          This course has a
          <strong>
           discussion section
          </strong>
          .
         </p>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="146">
            Civil Engineering
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="prerequisites">
          <li>
           Fluid Mechanics
          </li>
         </ul>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="ENGR-AD 349">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=ENGR-AD%20349">
          ENGR-AD 349 Mechatronics
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           The course introduces the principles of mechatronic system intended to provide the student with foundational concepts in mechatronics and practical familiarity with common elements making up mechatronic systems. Laboratory experiments are designed to give the student hands-on experience with components and measurement equipment used in the design of mechatronic products.
          </p>
         </div>
         <p class="lab">
          This course has a
          <strong>
           laboratory component
          </strong>
          .
         </p>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>

           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>

            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="145">

           </span>

           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>

It may be repeated for credits. The course is open to junior and senior students. Academic mentor's permission is required.
          </p>

           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="146">
            Civil Engineering
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">

           </span>

          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>

         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="ENGR-AD 381">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=ENGR-AD%20381">
          ENGR-AD 381 Bio-sensors and Bio-chips
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course covers the principles, technologies, methods and applications of biosensors and bioinstrumentation beginning with an examination of the ethical, legal, cultural, religious, and social implications of nanotechnologies. The objective of this course is to link engineering principles to understanding of biosystems in sensors and bioelectronics. It provides the student with detail of methods and procedures used in the design, fabrication, and application of biosensors and bioelectronic devices. The fundamentals of measurement science are applied to optical, electrochemical, mass, and pressure signal transduction. Upon successful completion of this course, students are expected to be able to explain biosensing and transducing techniques, design, and construct biosensors instrumentation.
          </p>
         </div>
         <p class="lab">
          This course has a
          <strong>
           laboratory component
          </strong>
          .
         </p>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2014
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/yong-song.html">
             Yong Song
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             U, 9:15-10:30 am (Sem); M 11:30-12:45 (Sem); M 1:30-4:00 pm (Lab)
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>

          <li class="section">

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="ENGR-AD 382">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=ENGR-AD%20382">
          ENGR-AD 382 Bio Imaging
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course presents an introduction to image formation, processing, and related techniques, as they pertain to imaging of biological structures for medical and other applications. Ultrasound, Magnetic Resonance Imaging, X-Ray Tomography, and Nuclear Medicine are among the topics covered, together with a hands-on introduction to biomedical image processing and pattern recognition.
          </p>
         </div>
         <p class="lab">
          This course has a
          <strong>
           laboratory component
          </strong>
          .
         </p>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="ENGR-AD 389">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=ENGR-AD%20389">
          ENGR-AD 389 Selected Topics in BioMedical and Health Systems
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course explores advanced topics of special interest in biomedical and health care systems and applications and is designed to aid students in gaining extra knowledge in an area not covered in the program's mainstay courses. It may be repeated for credit. The course is open to junior and senior students. Academic mentor's permission is required.
          </p>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="true" data-id="ENGR-AD 400">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=ENGR-AD%20400">
          ENGR-AD 400 Capstone Seminar
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           The goal of the Capstone Design Project is to provide students with a major design experience that leverages the knowledge and skills acquired through their undergraduate studies and co-curricular experiences. Its structure includes a process of design with measurable metrics, and incorporation of appropriate engineering standards and multiple realistic constraints. Emphasis is placed on clearly framing the design problem and following the design process to result in an optimized design solution. Students are encouraged to build prototypes of their designs and seek validation of their solutions through simulations and experiments, as appropriate.
          </p>
          <p>
           <span style="line-height:1.6em">
            The Capstone Project aims to be collaborative and trans-disciplinary across several engineering streams. The emphasis is on students applying the design process to solve real-world problems in a 21st century, global context.  The projects address engineering and technology topics that overlap with the sciences, social sciences, liberal arts or business. The Capstone provides an opportunity to integrate technical, human, aesthetic, business and ethical concerns with engineering design. Students practice critical skills in communication, team-building, and project management. There is a mid-semester review of the projects. Students complete their design, as well as build and test their prototypes, if applicable, in spring semester. The senior year culminates in a comprehensive project report and design review by a committee of faculty and other professionals.
           </span>
          </p>
          <p>
           Capstone Seminar (ENGR-AD-400), Capstone Design Project I (ENGR-AD-401) and Capstone Design Project II (ENGR-AD-402) collectively offer the engineering capstone experience to seniors. Capstone Seminar (Fall) and Capstone Design Project I (Fall) are two credits each. Capstone seminar focuses on skill building, project management and Ethics. Capstone Design Project I focus on different aspects of the capstone project such as problem definition and creating the design solution. Capstone Design Project II in spring consists of two, seven week modules. The design solution proposed in Capstone Design Project I is implemented in the first module. It is tested and validated in Module II.
          </p>
          <p>
           Prerequisite is Senior Standing
          </p>
          <p>
           (2 credits Fall semester)
          </p>
          <p>
           *Students must take ENGR-AD 400 and 401 concurrently.
          </p>
         </div>
         <p class="lab">
          This course has a
          <strong>
           laboratory component
          </strong>
          .
         </p>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2013
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="true" data-id="ENGR-AD 401">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=ENGR-AD%20401">
          ENGR-AD 401 Capstone Design Project I
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           The goal of the Capstone Design Project is to provide students with a major design experience that leverages the knowledge and skills acquired through their undergraduate studies and co-curricular experiences. Its structure includes a process of design with measurable metrics, and incorporation of appropriate engineering standards and multiple realistic constraints. Emphasis is placed on clearly framing the design problem and following the design process to result in an optimized design solution. Students are encouraged to build prototypes of their designs and seek validation of their solutions through simulations and experiments, as appropriate.
          </p>
          <p>
           <span style="line-height:1.6em">
            The Capstone Project aims to be collaborative and trans-disciplinary across several engineering streams. The emphasis is on students applying the design process to solve real-world problems in a 21st century, global context.  The projects address engineering and technology topics that overlap with the sciences, social sciences, liberal arts or business. The Capstone provides an opportunity to integrate technical, human, aesthetic, business and ethical concerns with engineering design. Students practice critical skills in communication, team-building, and project management. There is a mid-semester review of the projects. Students complete their design, as well as build and test their prototypes, if applicable, in spring semester. The senior year culminates in a comprehensive project report and design review by a committee of faculty and other professionals.
           </span>
          </p>
          <p>
           Capstone Seminar (ENGR-AD-400), Capstone Design Project I (ENGR-AD-401) and Capstone Design Project II (ENGR-AD-402) collectively offer the engineering capstone experience to seniors. Capstone Seminar (Fall) and Capstone Design Project I (Fall) are two credits each. Capstone seminar focuses on skill building, project management and Ethics. Capstone Design Project I focus on different aspects of the capstone project such as problem definition and creating the design solution. Capstone Design Project II in spring consists of two, seven week modules. The design solution proposed in Capstone Design Project I is implemented in the first module.         <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           The goal of the Capstone Design Project is to provide students with a major design experience that leverages the knowledge and skills acquired through their undergraduate studies and co-curricular experiences. Its structure includes a process of design with measurable metrics, and incorporation of appropriate engineering standards and multiple realistic constraints. Emphasis is placed on clearly framing the design problem and following the design process to result in an optimized design solution. Students are encouraged to build prototypes of their designs and seek validation of their solutions through simulations and experiments, as appropriate.
          </p>
          <p>
           The Capstone Project aims to be collaborative and trans-disciplinary across several engineering streams. The emphasis is on students applying the design process to solve real-world problems in a 21st century, global context.  The projects address engineering and technology topics that overlap with the sciences, social sciences, liberal arts or business. The Capstone provides an opportunity to integrate technical, human, aesthetic, business and ethical concerns with engineering design. Students practice critical skills in communication, team-building, and project management. There is a mid-semester review of the projects. Students complete their design, as well as build and test their prototypes, if applicable, in spring semester. The senior year culminates in a comprehensive project report and design review by a committee of faculty and other professionals.
          </p>
          <p>
           Capstone Seminar (ENGR-AD-400), Capstone Design Project I (ENGR-AD-401) and Capstone Design Project II (ENGR-AD-402) collectively offer the engineering capstone experience to seniors. Capstone Seminar (Fall) and Capstone Design Project I (Fall) are two credits each. Capstone seminar focuses on skill building, project management and Ethics. Capstone Design Project I focus on different aspects of the capstone project such as problem definition and creating the design solution. Capstone Design Project II in spring consists of two, seven week modules. The design solution proposed in Capstone Design Project I is implemented in the first module. It is tested and validated in Module II.
          </p>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="FILMM-AD 101">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=FILMM-AD%20101">
          FILMM-AD 101 Sound, Image, and Story
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           An intensive and practical production workshop introducing the fundamental principles of storytelling through sound, image, and visual sequencing. Using stills and video, integrating theory and practice, students learn the essentials of cinematic language from composition to editing. Themes of Sense of Place, Portrait, and Memoir are explored in the context of projects assigned. Diegetic and non-diegetic sound, and/or voiceover supplement the visual storytelling. Students work individually and in collaboration. Goals of the course include an understanding of professional protocol and the dialogue of critique. Four lab sessions outside of class are mandatory.
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Students in the NYUNY Tisch Film and Television Dept: This course counts for Film and Television core production course
           </em>
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Note: For the Fall 2013 offering, there will be screenings on various Wednesdays from 8:30-10:30pm. Please refer to Albert for more details.
           </em>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2012
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/joanne-savio.html">
             Joanne Savio
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             UW, 2:35-5:15
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2013
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="FILMM-AD 103">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=FILMM-AD%20103">
          FILMM-AD 103 Concepts of Film and New Media
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           An introduction to basic concepts in film and new media studies. The course provides an overview of the historical development of film as an art, science/technology, and industry and the role of new media as an extension to and reinvention of models for production, distribution, exhibition, and reception. Students are also introduced to documentary, experimental, and narratives modes within different historical and cultural contexts, comparative aesthetics, and the lines of critical enquiry that have been developed for film and new media in dialogue with other fields in the arts and humanities.
          </p>
          <p>
           (formerly titled Language of the Moving Image)
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Students in the NYUNY Film &amp; TV Dept: This course counts as a History and Criticism credit.
           </em>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2012
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="FILMM-AD 104X">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=FILMM-AD%20104X">
          FILMM-AD 104X Understanding MENASA Film and New Media
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course introduces students to the rich and diverse history of film within the Middle East, North Africa, and South Asia (MENASA) regions as a background for understanding some of the complexities of contemporary film and new media, particularly in the UAE.  By examining pre-cinematic artistic practices, aesthetic traditions, cinematic styles, political economies of media, and social change, the course provides a context for understanding productions from major industries in Cairo, Chennai, and Mumbai alongside work by independent filmmakers and new media collectives from throughout the regions.  Students are encouraged to attend film festivals and engage in original research with the NYUAD Library special collection of MENASA film.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2014
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/dale-hudson.html">
             Dale Hudson
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             MW, 9:15-10:30 am; U 6:00-9:30 pm
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>

           &gt;

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="FILMM-AD 105">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=FILMM-AD%20105">
          FILMM-AD 105 Forms of Writing for Film and New Media
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Whether narrative or non-narrative, the visceral, emotional, and intellectual power of film and new media depends on understanding the sounds and images within the context of conventions and expectations. This course analyzes and puts into practice principles of different forms of dramatic and dynamic writing: classical, episodic, and parametric in narrative and documentary; rhythmic and contrapuntal in experimental film; episodes and attractions for web platforms; interactive and auto-generative in new media. The course includes field trips as a study in location and place. Writing assignments include both critical analyses and creative exercises.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="required">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="11">
            Film and New Media
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="FILMM-AD 110">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=FILMM-AD%20110">
          FILMM-AD 110 Writing the Short Screenplay
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           A workshop designed to develop short screenplays from concept to structure to final draft. Topics include theme, character, research, story, conflict, dialogue, and script editing. The course aims to make a connection between the ancient traditions of the oral storyteller and the professional practice of the contemporary screenwriter when pitching to producers. Screenings and discussions focus on classical and contemporary examples of the short film from a variety of genres, traditions, and cultures. All students complete two short screenplays.
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Students in the NYUNY Tisch Film and Television Dept: This course is equivalent to
           </em>
           <em>
            FMTV-UT 1020 Writing the Short Screen Play
           </em>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2011

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="FILMM-AD 116J">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=FILMM-AD%20116J">
          FILMM-AD 116J Single Shot Cinema
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           In this hands-on course, we explore the vocabulary of camera movement and the dramatic impact of the long, single take. Single Shot Cinema is a film method that re-interprets film language based on the technical developments and possibilities of filmmaking in the digital age. What was once only possible with cranes and Steadicams is now accessible to the low-budget filmmaker. Students discover how to block actions and characters in a scene and how to choreograph one single shot, using smooth and flexible camera movements that expresses the drama, emotion, and vision of the director.
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Students in the NYUNY Tisch Film and Television Dept: This course counts for Film and Television as a 3-credit craft course
           </em>
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Students in the NYUNY Film &amp; TV Dept: This course counts as a Craft credit.
           </em>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2011
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            Leonard Retel Helmrich
								
								
								
									 -
            <span class="schedule">
             MR, 8:30-11:10
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            January 2014
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            Leonard Retel Helmrich
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Sydney, Australia
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="11">

           <span data-category="43">

           </span>

          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="FILMM-AD 117">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=FILMM-AD%20117">
          FILMM-AD 117 Directing the Camera 1
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course focuses on designing and executing the visual elements of a film. Through the universal language of lenses and lighting we learn how these play a central role when working with a set. Students develop the skills to use a motion picture camera in order to tell a good story. The class structure reflects a working film set with emphasis on production. Learning to create a mood advances the ultimate goal of a filmmaker. The heart of visual storytelling is composition: camera placement, camera angles, camera movement, and lens choice. Together with the lighting style a film finds its own unique life. In each class we look at selected scenes from popular films and recreate them. We shoot exercises in the classroom or on location.
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Students in the NYUNY Film &amp; TV Dept: This course counts as a Craft credit.
           </em>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2012
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/sandra-sissel.html">
             Sandra Sissel
            </a>
            -

            Film and New Media
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="43">
            Production
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="prerequisites">
          <li>
           Sound, Image, and Story
          </li>
         </ul>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="FILMM-AD 149">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=FILMM-AD%20149">
          FILMM-AD 149 Cinema and New Media
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course considers digital reformulations of the practice of cinema. What happens when film spectators become players of videogames, actors in locative media, or users of new media? What happens to the pleasures (cinephilia) and vulnerabilities (deterioration) of celluloid when we consider glossy compression formats and VOD (video on demand) distribution? How do the notions of virtual reality and artificial life intersect with “virtual migration” and “gold farming?” What can be learned about CGI (computer generated images) in relation to special effects achieved “in camera” or the optical printer? Students analyze an array of new media objects from around the world, as well as produce/ construct and distribute their own.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="175">
            Film and New Media
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="11">
            Film and New Media
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="167">
            Film and New Media Studies
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="11">
            Film and New Media
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="44">
            History, Theory, Criticism
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>

          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="FILMM-AD 150">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=FILMM-AD%20150">
          FILMM-AD 150 Frames of World Cinema: 1960 to present
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           World cinema typically has been studied as a collection of national traditions. What happens when the history of cinema is reframed within a set of regional, transnational, and global traditions? Students use film theory and close analysis to rethink the history of world cinema with particular emphasis on post-1960 Hollywood and New Wave films.
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Students in the NYUNY Tisch Film and Television Dept: This course is equivalent to FMTV-UT 322 International Cinema
           </em>
          </p>
         </div>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="FILMM-AD 151">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=FILMM-AD%20151">
          FILMM-AD 151 French New Wave Cinema
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course offers an historical/critical overview of one of the most influential film movements in the history of cinema—the French New Wave. After examining the philosophical underpinnings of the New Wave in philosophical existentialism (Sartre, de Beauvoir) and the movement’s theoretical underpinnings in the film criticism of Cahiers du Cinéma, we examine a chronological series of films by Cahiers directors (Truffaut, Godard, Chabrol, Rohmer), Left Bank directors (Resnais, Duras, Varda, Marker), and Cinéma Vérité (Rouch, Morin). While focusing on the films themselves, we also take a cultural studies approach by seeing the films as part of a broader artistic and mediatic spectrum.
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Students in the NYUNY Film &amp; TV Dept: This course counts as a History and Criticism credit.
           </em>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2013
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/robert-stam.html">
             Robert Stam
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             U, 1:00-3:30PM; W 11:35-12:50 PM
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>

          </strong>

            Concentrations

           &gt;

            Disciplinary Concentrations

           <span data-category="175">
            Film and New Media
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">

           </span>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="FILMM-AD 152">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=FILMM-AD%20152">
          FILMM-AD 152 Women, Film and Photography
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           In an art world saturated by men, do women offer another way of seeing? Through the genres of experimental, narrative, and documentary image-making, this course examines the work of women who have pioneered and re-imagined the methods, theories and ideas of the dominant culture. An eclectic and multi-cultural selection of feature length films, shorts, exhibitions, books and iconic images will be screened and studied. Students will write and critique, and look to their cultural milieu to make an image based project, and create oral/visual presentations. Field trips outside of class are mandatory.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2014
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/joanne-savio.html">
             Joanne Savio
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             T, 9:15-11:55 am
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>

           This course appears in...
          </strong>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="FILMM-AD 153">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=FILMM-AD%20153">
          FILMM-AD 153 Film Style: Theory and Practice
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course reveals how film style (cinematography, mise-en-scène, and editing) informs how we understand and emotionally respond to films. We will study closely the film style of film directors whose work exemplifies different elements of film style: mise-en-scène and the long take with static camera (Antonioni, Tsai, Tarr); editing in space, shot/reverse shot cutting, eye-line matches, and point-of-view editing (Hitchcock, Ozu); camera movement (Ophuls, Fellini, Tarkovsky); and sound/image montage (Lang, Bresson, Godard). Based on identical scripts, students (working in groups) will be assigned four practical film-based exercises modeled upon the films of these directors.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2015
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            Richard Allen
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="175">
            Film and New Media
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="11">
            Film and New Media
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="167">
            Film and New Media Studies
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="FILMM-AD 154">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=FILMM-AD%20154">
          FILMM-AD 154 Transtextuality: Adaptation Between Novel and Film
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course treats the theory, practice, and analysis of film adaptations of novels across a broad spectrum that includes novels by such figures as Defoe, Steinbeck, Nabokov, Flaubert, and Clarice Lispector. Combining close readings of the literary source-texts with close analysis of the films, the course will simultaneously explore the “transtextuality” theory that treats the complex and mutating relations between any single text and all the other texts, genres, media, and discourses with which it comes into dialogue. Through these contrapuntal analyses, the course will demonstrate the myriad ways that adaptation study can illuminate both media.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2015
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/robert-stam.html">
             Robert Stam
            </a>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>

           This course appears in...
          </strong>

            Film and New Media
           </span>

           </span>
          </li>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="FILMM-AD 155">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=FILMM-AD%20155">
          FILMM-AD 155 Stages of American Cinema: 1960 to Present
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course explores temporal stages of post-classical American cinema from the 1960s new wave to the new millennium global Hollywood. It also maps historically significant films on three broadly thematic stages: mind, society, and culture. Students acquire psychological, sociopolitical, and cultural perspectives in this regard, while learning about historical shifts, major genres and auteurs, and key issues on industry and technology. The course aims at shedding new synthetic light on the modern history of the world’s most powerful cinema.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2013
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/seung-hoon-jeong.html">
             Seung-Hoon Jeong
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             M, 8:30-10:30 PM (Lab); MW 4:00-5:15 PM
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>

           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="FILMM-AD 156">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=FILMM-AD%20156">
          FILMM-AD 156 Introduction to Film and New Media Curating
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Critical to the making and studies of film and new media are sensitivities to how audiences, spectators and publics are developed and effectively engaged. This course introduces students to contexts of visual literacies, concepts, methods and technologies of designing and mounting exhibitions for varieties of locations ranging from cinema halls to art fairs, museums to online platforms, public displays and other cultural spaces. Such skills will be developed side by side cultural and interpretive studies of politics and infrastructures of power, various social and historical contexts, models of cultural and art management, artistic practices and social movements and attitudes, conceptualizing and designing exhibitions.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="175">
            Film and New Media
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="11">
            Film and New Media
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="167">
            Film and New Media Studies
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="FILMM-AD 157J">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=FILMM-AD%20157J">
          FILMM-AD 157J Cinema and War
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course investigates the relationship of cinema and war from the early 20th century to the present. From the Libyan War of 1911-1912 onwards, film has been integral to shaping public consciousness of military events as they unfold and public memory of wars after the guns have fallen silent. The course looks at feature films and non-fiction, with government and clandestine short films shown as well as commercial entertainment films and independent documentaries. Topics to be addressed include how war’s many violences are represented; the filmmakers’ circumstances (censorship, political agendas and pressures, physical danger, the politics of funding); national cinemas; the role of sound; the camera as weapon; the uses of history; and the operation of memory. Case studies may include the two World Wars, civil wars (Spain, Lebanon), anti-colonial wars, the fall of Communism, the war in Iraq, Vietnam, the Israel-Palestinian conflict; and the Egyptian revolution.
          </p>
          <p>
           *For NYU New York and NYU Shanghai students interested in this course, please submit the
           <a href="http://nyuad.nyu.edu/en/academics/global-education/jterm-application-nyu.html">
            application
           </a>
           by October 15th. For more information about NYU Abu Dhabi courses being offered during January term visit our
           <a href="http://www.nyu.edu/admissions/january-term/nyu-abu-dhabi-january-term.html">
            website
           </a>
           .
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            January 2015
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            Ruth Ben-Ghiat
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="175">
            Film and New Media
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="3">
            Multidisciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="166">
            Peace Studies
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="11">
            Film and New Media
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="167">
            Film and New Media Studies
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="FILMM-AD 198">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=FILMM-AD%20198">
          FILMM-AD 198 Directed Study
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Offered by application Prerequisite: permission of the instructor Closely supervised individual research on a particular topic, undertaken by arrangement with an individual faculty member, resulting in a substantial paper.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>

         <ul class="appearances">

        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="FILMM-AD 201">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=FILMM-AD%20201">
          FILMM-AD 201 Intermediate Filmmaking
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course is designed to develop techniques and skills in generating ideas for short films that are shot on digital video and edited on nonlinear editing software. It will focus on strong visualization of story and camera techniques, as opposed to dialogue-based work. Students will develop skills in the elements of visual storytelling through the process of storyboarding and creating shot lists, then working in small crews to direct and shoot the projects. Students will gain knowledge of new photographic techniques, moving the camera dynamically, and the ways in which the craft of editing and sound design can be used to support story.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2014
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/wendy-bednarz.html">
             Wendy Bednarz
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             MW, 12:45-3:15 pm
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="175">
            Film and New Media
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="11">
            Film and New Media
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="168">
            Film and New Media Practice
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="prerequisites">
          <li>
           Sound, Image, and Story
          </li>
          <li>
           Forms of Writing for Film and New Media
          </li>
         </ul>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="FILMM-AD 209">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=FILMM-AD%20209">
          FILMM-AD 209 Documentary Techniques and Production
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           A practical introduction to creating compelling stories in which real people are the characters and real life is the plot. The academic study of classic documentaries is combined with craft training and a review of documentary film styles. Practical exercises are assigned weekly. Working collaboratively in small production teams, each student completes a short documentary portrait. The course includes the introduction of digital filmmaking fundamentals: lighting, camera, and sound recording. The creative role of the editor is also emphasized. Students learn to understand how pacing, transitions, cuts, and continuity can enhance a documentary film.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="175">
            Film and New Media
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="11">
            Film and New Media
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="168">
            Film and New Media Practice
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="11">
            Film and New Media
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="43">
            Production
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="prerequisites">
          <li>
           Sound, Image, and Story
          </li>
         </ul>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="FILMM-AD 210">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=FILMM-AD%20210">
          FILMM-AD 210 Introduction to Animation
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           A practical introduction to the basic techniques of animation. Topics include flipbook, clay, collage, and drawing from the model. Cameraless animation, optical toys and 2-D digital animation are also explored. Principles of motion are stressed such as anticipation, follow-through, staging, overlapping action, and exaggeration, among others. All work is tested on video. At the end of the course each student will have an edited two-minute reel.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2 2013
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            7 Weeks
           </span>

									 -
            <span class="schedule">
             UTR, 9:55- 12:35 PM
            </span>
            <br/>

           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>

            Film and New Media
           </span>

          <li class="elective">

           </span>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="FILMM-AD 211">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=FILMM-AD%20211">
          FILMM-AD 211 Person-to-Person: The Interview
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Exploring the interview in film, radio, television, print, and new media, this class considers a range of theoretical and practical approaches to the shaping of questions, the interviewer/interviewee relationship, character, and constructing an argument. Readings include Plato, Deleuze, and Studs Terkel and the class examines the approaches of Errol Morris, Michael Moore, Sadie Benning, David Frost, James Agee, Oprah Winfrey, and others. Class projects investigate these techniques from both a practical and theoretical perspective.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="11">
            Film and New Media
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="43">
            Production
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="FILMM-AD 212">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=FILMM-AD%20212">
          FILMM-AD 212 Short Film Production
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           In this practical introduction to short filmmaking each student writes and directs three short fiction films, wokring in groups of four and rotating crew positions. Student work is screened and critiqued in class. Students are introduced to the fundamentals of screenwriting, acting, directing, lighting, and sound recording, and working with HD or SD video. Digital editing tools including Final Cut Pro are utilized. Digital output, compression, and online distribution is also covered.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2013
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            Scandar Copti
								
								
								
									 -
            <span class="schedule">
             M, 9:55-11:10 AM; W 9:55-12:35 PM
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="11">

           </span>

           <span data-category="43">

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="FILMM-AD 213">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=FILMM-AD%20213">
          FILMM-AD 213 Social Software
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Traditional broadcast media (television and radio) are in a time of transition, pushed in new directions by the increasing ease of producing compelling material, and by the interactive and social nature of the Internet. Blogs and other Internet-based social networks have given rise to an audience that is eager to engage with and participate in the creation of media. The goal of this course is to introduce students to new technologies and methods for creating participatory media and making it available to the public. Students develop new ideas for helping this transition along both on the Internet and in the traditional broadcast space.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="11">
            Film and New Media
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="43">
            Production
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="FILMM-AD 214">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=FILMM-AD%20214">
          FILMM-AD 214 Developing the Feature
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           A workshop devoted to the development of a feature-length screenplay. Topics include the germinal idea, research, the step outline, and the first draft. Students are encouraged to develop original ideas, create memorable characters, construct effective stories and structures, and write distinctive dialogues. Students workshop their story ideas and screenplay pages in class.
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Students in the NYUNY Film &amp; TV Dept: This course counts as a Scriptwriting credit.
           </em>
          </p>
         </div>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="FILMM-AD 215">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=FILMM-AD%20215">
          FILMM-AD 215 Film Techniques: Story and Style
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course is designed to give student filmmakers more authority in applying techniques to telling a story visually. These techniques include choice of locations, casting, color palette and production design, camera work, lighting, mise-en-scène, editing, and sound design. Emphasis is given to translating a script into techniques that create a coherent style. The course emphasizes weekly exercises (outside of class, with digital camera), critical readings, and close reading of clips from films produced around the world from the early 1900s to today.
          </p>
          <p>
           *Note: Prequisites for this course include Film and New Media major or permission of the instructor.
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Students in the NYUNY Film &amp; TV Dept: This course counts as a Craft credit.
           </em>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2013
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/gail-segal.html">
             Gail Segal
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">

            </span>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="FILMM-AD 216">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=FILMM-AD%20216">
          FILMM-AD 216 Directing the Non-actor: Singular Drama
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This practical workshop offers students hands-on insight into the process of creating drama in a film using the human capacity to respond emotionally to a fictional situation. Students learn how to direct films that have a precise screenplay and a well-constructed plot in a way that brings non-actors to act out a story without being aware that they are being directed according to a pre-written script.
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Students in the NYUNY Film &amp; TV Dept: This course counts as a Craft credit.
           </em>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2013
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            Scandar Copti
								
								
								
									 -
            <span class="schedule">
             M, 9:35-10:35 AM
            </span>
            <br/>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="FILMM-AD 217">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=FILMM-AD%20217">
          FILMM-AD 217 Directing the Camera 2
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course extends the reach of students who have taken Directing the Camera I or its equivalent. It is designed especially for capstone students who are creating 10-12-minute films and will coordinate with the courses
           <em>
            Directing the Non-Actor
           </em>
           and
           <em>
            Writing the Short Screenplay
           </em>
           to encourage students to develop multiple skills in their crafting of their capstone project.
          </p>
          <p>
           Prerequisites: For non-capstone students,
           <em>
            Directing the Camera 1
           </em>
           (FILMM-AD 117). No prerequisites for capstone students.
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Students in the NYUNY Film &amp; TV Dept: This course counts as a Craft credit.
           </em>
          </p>
          <p>
          </p>
          <p>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2013
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>

             Sandra Sissel
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             W, 9:00-12:00 PM
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>

          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="FILMM-AD 218">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=FILMM-AD%20218">
          FILMM-AD 218 Intermediate Production
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           tbd
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="FILMM-AD 219">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=FILMM-AD%20219">
          FILMM-AD 219 Communication Lab
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           A production based course that surveys various technologies including digital imaging, video, audio, animation, and basic web development. The forms and uses of new communications technologies are explored in a laboratory context of experimentation and discussion. Principles of interpersonal communications and media theory are introduced.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="FILMM-AD 221">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=FILMM-AD%20221">
          FILMM-AD 221 Shorts into Series, Back Again, and Beyond
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course examines migrations of the short format from the silent era through its serialization as episodes in long-format narrative, such as television series and video games. The course explores the aesthetics and politics of looking from peep shows and television flows into video-on-demand and webcam surveillance, focusing professional and nonprofessional productions. Topics may include: exhibition platforms from nickelodeons to social media, music videos, Brazilian and Mexican telenovelas, Indian mythologicals, Nollywood video-films, Ramadan serials, Korean dramas, video mashups and GIFs, console video games, vlogs, global talent-show and reality-television franchises, and animated series including Freej.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">

           &gt;

            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="175">
            Film and New Media
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="11">
            Film and New Media
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="167">
            Film and New Media Studies
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="FILMM-AD 222">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=FILMM-AD%20222">
          FILMM-AD 222 Comparative (Post)Colonialism: Media and Representation
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This seminar is devoted to the interrelated issues of colonialism, postcolonialism, comparative race, and multiculturalism as apprehended through diverse disciplines, media, and colonial histories. Throughout our focus is comparative, transnational and trans- disciplinary, mingling the theories and methods of media studies, literary studies, philosophy, and social studies. The goal is to reflect in a polycentric way on a multicultural world still shaped by the legacies of (post) colonialism, as reflected, refracted, translated, and resisted by the media.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="11">
            Film and New Media
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="44">
            History, Theory, Criticism
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="FILMM-AD 223">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=FILMM-AD%20223">
          FILMM-AD 223 Documentary Techniques
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           The course provides a review of current documentaries and a comparison with those made in earlier decades. We examine influential works such as Robert Flaherty’s Nanook of the North, propaganda films, cinéma vérité, social and educational documentaries, the personal documentary, re-enactment and dramatization, experimental works, and the unique voices of artists such as Errol Morris. The course explores the different genres of documentary filmmaking and identifies the specific elements employed in the context of their time, their objective, and their audience. The final project: a 5-7–minute documentary portrait of “a character work.” This course also includes a final exam.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2012
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>

             Gail Segal
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             M, 4:00-6:00
            </span>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="FILMM-AD 224">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=FILMM-AD%20224">
          FILMM-AD 224 Methods of Editing
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           The emphasis of the course is on storytelling. The class has two components: lectures, in which concepts are discussed and demonstrated and work-in-progress sessions in which students screen and critique each others work. Students work toward the completion of a short film. Seniors are encouraged to edit their Capstone films.
          </p>
          <p>
           *Crosslisting as HTC and an Arts Practice course only for Spring 2014.
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Students in the NYUNY Film &amp; TV Dept: This course counts as a Craft credit.
           </em>
