       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="HIST-AD 158">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=HIST-AD%20158">
          HIST-AD 158 Two Europes: Islam and Christendom, 711-1529
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           The course explores the economic, political, and cultural asymmetries of the long symbiosis when Europe was divided at the Pyrenees into a Muslim and a Christian sphere. Al-Andalus (Muslim Spain) was religiously tolerant, culturally rich, and economically robust. Carolingian and post-Carolingian Europe were economically retarded and culturally impoverished. By the beginning of the 12th century, a Christian reconquest overwhelmed the Muslim Andalusia. Nevertheless, an Indian summer of interfaith collaboration of Christian, Muslim, and Jew persisted.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="120">
            History
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="12">
            History
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="48">
            Atlantic World
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="HIST-AD 159">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=HIST-AD%20159">
          HIST-AD 159 Imperial Competition in the 19th and 20th Centuries
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Throughout the 19th and 20th centuries, empires competed with each other both inside the Atlantic and European world and beyond it in Africa, Asia, and Eurasia. This course explores the strategies of British, French, Russian, Ottoman, German, Habsburg, American, and Soviet empires through World War II.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="HIST-AD 161">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=HIST-AD%20161">
          HIST-AD 161 Islam in Africa and the Americas
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Introduced by merchant activity in the 8th century C.E., by the 15th century Islam had become the religion of ruling elites throughout much of the western Sudan, and was the foundation for significant urban development in East Africa. This course examines both the impact of 17th-19th-century Islamic reform in West Africa and the transatlantic slave trade, and the influence and legacy of African Muslims exported to the Americas via the slave trade. Finally, we consider the contemporary Muslim experience in both Africa and the Americas.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="120">
            History
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="12">
            History
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="48">
            Atlantic World
           </span>
          </li>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="HIST-AD 162">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=HIST-AD%20162">
          HIST-AD 162 Topics in Atlantic History
         </a>

          <p>
           Course topics may include The Enlightenment; American colonial history; Atlantic immigration; race, gender, and sexuality in U.S. history; African- American history; New York City past and present; women and slavery in the Americas; the New Deal; and others.
          </p>

       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="HIST-AD 163">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=HIST-AD%20163">
          HIST-AD 163 Ideas into Ideologies: Nineteenth-Century German Ideas and Their Global Legacies
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           What makes ideas historical? How do ideas travel beyond their originating contexts and become embedded in different temporal, linguistic, and cultural settings, often with vastly unexpected consequences? How do intellectuals feature as cultural agents and producers of ideology in such processes? The course explores these and other issues by following the trajectories of some influential ideas articulated in German letters during the “Long Nineteenth Century” (1789–1914) and seeks to explain the diverse European and global legacies they inspired during and after this period. Focusing on the interplay between theory and practice, the course investigates how such ideas changed in the course of their dissemination, appropriation, and re-interpretation, in ways that radically transformed the modern world.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="120">
            History
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="12">
            History
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="48">
            Atlantic World
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="HIST-AD 164">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=HIST-AD%20164">
          HIST-AD 164 Urbanism and Modernity: Paris, Istanbul, Berlin
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course explores the emergence of the “modern city” in three significant urban centers (Paris, Istanbul, Berlin) in relation to the demographic, economic, and political pressures of the nineteenth and twentieth centuries. Attention is given to the foundations of community, the changing uses of public space, the appearance of new strategies of urban planning, and the contested process of defining the “modern” within a specific local culture.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2011
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/nadine-roth.html">
             Nadine Roth
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             MR, 9:55-11:10
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2012
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="HIST-AD 166">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=HIST-AD%20166">
          HIST-AD 166 Ethnicity, Race, and Immigration in United States History
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course covers the basic immigration, ethnic, and racial history of the US from colonial times through the present. Which population groups arrived when, and with what political and cultural consequences for themselves and for other groups? How has public and private authority dealt with ethnic and racial diversity in the most conspicuous of the immigrant-receiving nations in the world, and one with egalitarian aspirations? What ideas about diversity and cosmopolitanism have developed in this American context?
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Students in the NYUNY History Dept: This course counts for History special topics lecture credit
           </em>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 1 2012
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            7 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            David Hollinger
								
								
								
									 -
            <span class="schedule">
             MR, 1:10-3:50
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="HIST-AD 167">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=HIST-AD%20167">
          HIST-AD 167 United Statesin a Transnational and Global Perspective 1: America and the World Until 1898
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Rethinking the traditional narratives of U.S. history, this course explores America’s past from a transnational and global perspective. Chronologically, it covers America's interaction with the wider world from the earliest European settlements to the Spanish-American War of 1898, examining the Colonial Period, the Revolutionary War, the founding of the republic, the War of 1812, westward expansion, as well as the Civil War, the abolition of slavery, and Reconstruction. Readings and classroom discussions focus on the major political, economic, and cultural forces that shaped the process of American nation-building, reevaluating the allegedly "exceptional" elements of U.S. history in relation to networks, identities, and events that transcended the nation-state.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2013
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/martin-klimke.html">
             Martin Klimke
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             UW, 11:20-12:35 PM
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>

           </span>
          </li>

         </p>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="HIST-AD 168">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=HIST-AD%20168">
          HIST-AD 168 United States in a Transnational and Global Perspective 2: America and the World Since 1898
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Rethinking the traditional narratives of U.S. history, this course explores the country’s past from a transnational and global perspective. Chronologically, it covers America's interaction with the wider world from the Spanish-American War to the presidency of Barack Obama, examining America’s emergence as a global power leading up to World War I, the progressive reform movement, the Great Depression and the New Deal, World War II, the Cold War, the African American civil rights struggle, the political turmoil of the 1960s, Watergate, as well as the "conservative revolution" of the 1980s, the end of the Cold War and America after 9/11. Readings and classroom discussions focus on the major political, economic, and cultural forces that shaped the "American century" and the country’s present, reevaluating the allegedly "exceptional" elements of U.S. history in relation to networks, identities, and events that transcended the nation-state.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2014
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/martin-klimke.html">
             Martin Klimke
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             MW, 11:20-12:35 pm
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="HIST-AD 169">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=HIST-AD%20169">
          HIST-AD 169 From the "Chilean Road to Socialism" to the Pinochet Era: Chile and the Global Cold War
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course explores some of Latin America’s most significant social and political events during the Cold War: the democratic election in 1970 of a Marxist president in Chile, his overthrow by a military coup d’état in 1973, and the installation of a military regime led by General Augusto Pinochet that lasted until 1989. During this period, Chile attracted the world’s attention for many different reasons. Among them was the experimental nature of its social and political transformations, namely a democratic transition to socialism, as well as the authoritarian implantation of neo-liberal policies.
          </p>
          <p>
           This course seeks to understand both of these experiments, focusing on their global connections beyond the well-known diplomatic tensions of the Cold War. Along with an analysis of Chile's social structure, political system, and economic history, this course will highlight the importance of gender roles, subaltern agency, and popular movements. Finally, the course will also address the traumatic dimension of Chile’s Cold War experience trough the study of violence, truth, and memory during Pinochet’s regime.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2015
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            Martin Bowen-Silva
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>

           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="12">

           <span data-category="48">
            Atlantic World
           </span>
          </li>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="HIST-AD 170">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=HIST-AD%20170">
          HIST-AD 170 Ancient Near East
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Civilization in the Fertile Crescent and Egypt from the prehistoric period up to the rise of Islam. Stresses the development of political, economic, and religious institutions. Students learn about the interaction of the great empires of the Near East and about the impact that these empires have had on world civilization and culture.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="HIST-AD 171">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=HIST-AD%20171">
          HIST-AD 171 Ancient Mediterranean World
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           The ancient Mediterranean, from Spain to Egypt and the Levant, is the cradle from which Western civilization grew. This course covers the different cultures of the region, with particular interest in their interaction and the conquest of the entire region by Rome. The course examines the complex dynamics of Rome’s relationship to its subject peoples, as Roman trappings were overlaid upon native traditions.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>

           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="120">
            History
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="HIST-AD 172">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=HIST-AD%20172">
          HIST-AD 172 The Crusades
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           The history of the Crusades (1095–1291 C.E.) is an important chapter in European imperialism and a manifestation of deep religious conviction. Examines the background in Europe leading to the Crusades; the social, political, and economic situation in the eastern Mediterranean before the Crusades; the fortunes of the Crusader (Latin) Kingdom of Jerusalem; and the reactions of Europeans and Easterners to one another. Examines and reevaluates the legacy of the Crusades on both the Eastern and the Western worlds.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>

           &gt;

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="HIST-AD 173">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=HIST-AD%20173">
          HIST-AD 173 Central Asia and the Middle East
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           TThis course examines the interconnected histories, cultures, and societies of Central Asia and the Middle East. It will begin with an overview of the Mongol empire and its legacies in Central Asia and the broader Muslim world. We will compare the emerging post-Mongol Eurasian and Ottoman states through the lenses of law, political legitimacy, succession, and ruling institutions. We will then compare Russian and Ottoman civilizing missions, imperial nationalisms, treatments of sectarianism and ethnic minorities, constitutionalisms, public health policies, responses to Islamic modernism, Marxist and other radical leftist ideas, and women’s emancipation. The course will conclude by considering how post-imperial modernization projects transformed identity, gender, and religion in Central Asia and the Middle East.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2015
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/masha-kirasirova.html">
             Masha Kirasirova
            </a>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>

          <strong>
           This course appears in...

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="HIST-AD 175">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=HIST-AD%20175">
          HIST-AD 175 Ottoman Empire in World History
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           The course examines the Ottoman Empire from a world historical perspective. Beginning with the collapse of the Byzantine state and ending with the French Revolution, students gain an understanding of the Ottoman state and society and its responses to, and participation in, global trade, interstate warfare, and the cultural and political development of the modern world.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">

           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="3">
            Multidisciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="32">
            The Arab Crossroads
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>

        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=HIST-AD%20176">
          HIST-AD 176 Topics in Mediterranean History
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Topics may include history of Egypt; the Roman Empire; religion and culture from Alexander to Muhammad; Venice and the Mediterranean; premodern science; Western expansion in the Eastern Mediterranean, 11th–15th centuries; Napoleon; modern Greek history; Israel and Palestine; and others.
          </p>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="HIST-AD 177J">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=HIST-AD%20177J">
          HIST-AD 177J Renaissance Humanism and Humanity Today
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This intellectual history course examines the emergence of Renaissance humanism, particularly in Florence from Petrarch to Pico and Machiavelli, by examining the political and cultural foundations of humanism, the turn toward Ancient Greece and Rome, and the establishment of a human-centered point of view in poetry, philosophy, religious thought, and art. What picture of the human being emerged with this turn? How did the turn toward the Classics contribute to the development of modern humanism? How was this humanism itself taken up in the Enlightenment and the development of modern education systems, and what remains of humanism today?
          </p>
          <p>
           *For NYU New York and NYU Shanghai students interested in this course, please submit the
           <a href="http://nyuad.nyu.edu/en/academics/global-education/jterm-application-nyu.html">
            application
           </a>
           by October 15th. For more information about NYU Abu Dhabi courses being offered during January term visit our
           <a href="http://www.nyu.edu/admissions/january-term/nyu-abu-dhabi-january-term.html">
            website
           </a>
           .
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            January 2015
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            Stefanos N. Geroulanos
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Florence, Italy
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>

            Concentrations

           &gt;

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="HIST-AD 400">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=HIST-AD%20400">
          HIST-AD 400 Senior Capstone Research Project (2 Semesters)
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           The capstone experience provides seniors with the opportunity to work closely with a faculty mentor and to conduct extensive research on a topic of their choice. The program consists of a capstone seminar, taken in the first semester of the senior year, and a year-long individualized thesis tutorial. During the capstone seminar, students define a thesis topic of their choice, develop a bibliography, read broadly in background works, and begin their research. In the tutorial, students work on a one-to-one basis with a faculty director to hone their research and produce successive drafts of a senior thesis. The capstone experience culminates in the public presentation of the senior thesis. Students may also elect to participate in a College Capstone Project with students majoring in other disciplines in the arts, and the natural and social sciences. Collaborating students work with a faculty member to define the overall goals of the Capstone Project, as well as the particular goals of each participant.
          </p>
          <p>
          </p>
          <p>
           *NOTE: As of Fall 2013 Capstone under HUM-AD 400
          </p>
         </div>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="HIST-AD 401">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=HIST-AD%20401">
          HIST-AD 401 Senior Capstone Research Project ( 2 Semesters)
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           The capstone experience provides seniors with the opportunity to work closely with a faculty mentor and to conduct extensive research on a topic of their choice. The program consists of a capstone seminar, taken in the first semester of the senior year, and a year-long individualized thesis tutorial. During the capstone seminar, students define a thesis topic of their choice, develop a bibliography, read broadly in background works, and begin their research. In the tutorial, students work on a one-to-one basis with a faculty director to hone their research and produce successive drafts of a senior thesis. The capstone experience culminates in the public presentation of the senior thesis. Students may also elect to participate in a College Capstone Project with students majoring in other disciplines in the arts, and the natural and social sciences. Collaborating students work with a faculty member to define the overall goals of the Capstone Project, as well as the particular goals of each participant.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>

        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=HUM-AD%20400">
          HUM-AD 400 Capstone Research Project
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           The capstone experience provides seniors with the opportunity to work closely with a faculty mentor and to conduct extensive research on a topic of their choice. The program consists of a capstone seminar, taken in the first semester of the senior year, and a year-long individualized thesis tutorial. During the capstone seminar, students define a thesis topic of their choice, develop a bibliography, read broadly in background works, and begin their research. In the tutorial, students work on a one-to-one basis with a faculty director to hone their research and produce successive drafts of a senior thesis. The capstone experience culminates in the public presentation of the senior thesis.
          </p>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="JOUR-AD 110">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=JOUR-AD%20110">
          JOUR-AD 110 Foundations of Journalism
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Students explore the significance of news, the role of the journalist from Thucydides to the present, and the realities journalists now face in a rapidly changing media environment.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="4">
            Pre-Professional Courses
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="38">
            Journalism
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="JOUR-AD 114J">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=JOUR-AD%20114J">
          JOUR-AD 114J Food in the Global Kitchen
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Abu Dhabi contains many worlds, from five-star hotel restaurants to South Asian migrant workers eating on the job. This course uses food to explore the daily life of a global city in the Middle East. The course combines intensive reading and writing assignments with reporting and field trips. With Abu Dhabi as their beat, students explore the role of markets; traditional bedouin cuisine and the rituals of eating it; the hidden lives of food producers and growers; the cuisine of exile; the business of food; edible geography; and other topics drawing on anthropology, economics, culture, politics, and urban studies. Students participate in hands-on experiences like visits to local markets and restaurants. Each student are expected to find, report, and write a feature article about a food-related location in Abu Dhabi. Readings range from medieval Arabic culinary manuals and classics of cultural anthropology to contemporary food reporting and literature, with an emphasis on the Middle East.
          </p>
          <p>
           *For NYU New York and NYU Shanghai students interested in this course, please submit the
           <a href="http://nyuad.nyu.edu/en/academics/global-education/jterm-application-nyu.html">
            application
           </a>
           by October 15th. For more information about NYU Abu Dhabi courses being offered during January term visit our
           <a href="http://www.nyu.edu/admissions/january-term/nyu-abu-dhabi-january-term.html">
            website
           </a>
           .
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            January 2013
           </span>

            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             T, BD

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="JOUR-AD 210">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=JOUR-AD%20210">
          JOUR-AD 210 Journalistic Inquiry
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This first-level reporting, research, and writing course emphasizes in-depth research and interviewing technique as it introduces a variety of journalistic forms, including the reported essay, the newspaper pyramid style, magazine and newspaper feature style, broadcast news-writing style, and writing for the Web. This course provides a strong foundation in basic journalistic forms, issues, and responsibilities.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="prerequisites">
          <li>
           Foundations of Journalism
          </li>
         </ul>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="JOUR-AD 211">

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="JOUR-AD 213">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=JOUR-AD%20213">
          JOUR-AD 213 Media Criticism
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course analyzes the forces—cultural, social, economic, ideological, and aesthetic—that shape the media and their messages.

         <ul class="sections">

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="LAW-AD 114J">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=LAW-AD%20114J">
          LAW-AD 114J Punishment in Politics, Law and Society
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This seminar investigates the state’s power to punish. We read foundational works from philosophy, sociology, political science, and law to explore why states punish, how they punish, and whom they punish. We focus on the modern American approach to punishment, including its use of mass incarceration and the death penalty. We analyze U.S. Supreme Court cases in light of the fundamental purposes of punishment, and compare penal practices around the world. Though subject to change, activities outside the classroom may include attending arraignment court, observing a sentencing hearing, and visiting a correctional facility.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            January 2013
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/rachel-barkow.html">
             Rachel Barkow
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             T, BD
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             New York City
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            January 2014
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/rachel-barkow.html">
             Rachel Barkow
            </a>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             New York City
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>

           &gt;

            Political Science
           </span>

           </span>
          </li>

          There are no prerequisites for this course.

       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="LAW-AD 210">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=LAW-AD%20210">
          LAW-AD 210 Civil Rights
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Interpretation of the Bill of Rights, the Civil War amendments, and other rights in the U.S. Constitution through the reading of Supreme Court opinions. Topics include freedom of speech and press; free exercise of religion and separation of church and state; the right of privacy; rights of the criminally accused; equal protection of the law against race, gender, and other discrimination; and the rights of franchise and citizenship. Cases are read and discussed closely for their legal and philosophical content.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="4">
            Pre-Professional Courses
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="39">
            Law
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="LAW-AD 211">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=LAW-AD%20211">
          LAW-AD 211 Gender in Law
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Examines the relationship between gender politics, legal theory, and social policy. Studies the role that the legal arena and certain historical conditions have played in creating, revising, and protecting particular gender identities and not others and examines the political effects of those legal constructions.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="4">
            Pre-Professional Courses
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="39">
            Law
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="LAW-AD 212J">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=LAW-AD%20212J">
          LAW-AD 212J International Law
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           The course addresses the norms that govern states in their legal relations with each other, including those that affect how states treat persons within their territories. The focus is on understanding the basic sources of international law (treaties and customary law) as well as the actors that influence their development, interpretation, and enforcement (especially governments, international organizations, non-governmental organizations, and international courts). Topcics include: the role and function of the United Nations, international responsibility and the protection of aliens and their property, the regulation of the use of force, and recent developments in international criminal law (including the establishment and function of the International Court of Justice), and the impact of the "human rights revolution." Select class outings and visitors to the class, based in Buenos Aires, introduce students to the regional implications and applications of international law.
          </p>
          <p>
           *For NYU New York and NYU Shanghai students interested in this course, please submit the
           <a href="http://nyuad.nyu.edu/en/academics/global-education/jterm-application-nyu.html">
            application
           </a>
           by October 15th. For more information about NYU Abu Dhabi courses being offered during January term visit our
           <a href="http://www.nyu.edu/admissions/january-term/nyu-abu-dhabi-january-term.html">
            website
           </a>
           .
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="LAW-AD 213">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=LAW-AD%20213">
          LAW-AD 213 Climate Change Law and Policy
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Climate change will be a foremost theme that will influence financial activities, and policy and legal framework for years to come. In a noticeably short time span, climate change has become a global challenge calling for collective action. Climate change law is emerging as a new legal discipline. Students in this course will explore how climate change law relates to other areas of law and how climate change has elicited rulemaking process at the international, regional, national and local levels. The course will encourage students to identify the climate change policy issues in state and international laws. Students will also study how international law and international relations influence current national laws and policies. The class will be invited to study the negotiation process, implementation and current status of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), the Kyoto Protocol, the Copenhagen Accord, the Cancun and Durban Agreements. The class will then proceed to evaluate the various legal tools that are available at national and international level to address climate change, including cap-and-trade, carbon taxation, command-and-control regulation, litigation, securities disclosures, and voluntary actions. The class will also examine energy and climate change nexus and the roles of energy efficiency, renewable energy sources and carbon capture and sequestration. The course will pay special attention to the role of developing countries in the emerging international climate change regime and negotiation strategies of G77+China in Copenhagen, Cancun, Durban, Doha, Warsaw, and upcoming UNFCCC conference in Peru in December 2014.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2014
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/shakeel-kazmi.html">
             Shakeel Kazmi
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             MW, 12:45-2:00 pm
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>

          </strong>

          <li class="elective">

           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="39">
            Law
           </span>
          </li>

          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="LAW-AD 214">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=LAW-AD%20214">
          LAW-AD 214 Comparative Legal Systems: United States and United Arab Emirates
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           The growing trend of globalization in nearly every field of human endeavor, demands legal experts to get awareness of legal traditions and systems operating beyond their borders. This course will invite students to explore the legal systems of other than their own native legal system. Primarily this course will focus on essential characteristics of the three major legal systems: Civil, Common, and Islamic and Sharia. The class will also examine the diverse legal systems, inspired by various political, social, and religious doctrines, successfully used by billions of people in various parts of the world. This course will pay special attention to law traditions explicitly functioning in United States of America, and United Arab Emirates. This class will offer a historical and cultural background related to the development of legal structures and substantive rules in both territories. Students will study existing judicial systems, and essential rules dealing with legal education and practice in U.S. and Emirates.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2014
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/shakeel-kazmi.html">
             Shakeel Kazmi
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             MW, 3:35-4:50 pm
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="LEAD-AD 110">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=LEAD-AD%20110">
          LEAD-AD 110 Social Entrepreneurship and Innovation
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course provides a broad introduction to the role of organizations and entrepreneurs in achieving social impact through their work. The course examines the definition of social entrepreneurship and different strategies for creating ideas that help solve pressing social issues such as poverty, illiteracy, hunger, economic opportunity, and disease. Students work in teams to develop venture plans for implementing an entrepreneurial idea. The course examines social entrepreneurship in a variety of settings, including government, nongovernmental organizations, and the private sector.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="4">
            Pre-Professional Courses
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="40">
            Leadership and Social Entrepreneurship
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="LEAD-AD 115J">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=LEAD-AD%20115J">
          LEAD-AD 115J Critical Issues in Social Entrepreneurship: Innovations in the Middle East
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Social Entrepreneurship is a dynamic and growing field which may be defined in various ways, yet at its core is about using evolved business thinking and practices to change the world. This course provides an introduction to the topic through discussion of how social entrepreneurs develop their ideas of social and environmental innovation, how they fund/finance their ventures, the ways in which they overcome the challenges of integrating various levels of economic performance with social/environmental impact, and the types of organizations social entrepreneurs create (for-profit, non-profit, cooperative, hybrid, etc). Through a "deep dive" case study of a leading social enterprise, we explore the relevance of social entrepreneurship in a changing world and heighten our understanding of the potential we each hold to be "change makers."
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            January 2013
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="LEAD-AD 210">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=LEAD-AD%20210">
          LEAD-AD 210 Models of Leadership
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course examines the role and meaning of leadership within work organizations, communities, markets, and governments. Students are introduced to different theories and models of leadership, and are encouraged to examine their own leadership styles. The impact of history, culture, and circumstance on how we define and identify leaders is examined.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="LEAD-AD 211">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=LEAD-AD%20211">
          LEAD-AD 211 Policy Studies
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course introduces specific analytical tools useful for effectively assessing public policies and social issues. It surveys the topics central to the task of policy analysis: how problems are defined, how information is collected, how relative costs and benefits of policy are assessed, how policy solutions are formulated and adopted, and how ethics inform policy analysis. Students conduct a series of policy debates.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>

           &gt;
           <span data-category="40">

           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>

          </strong>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="LITCW-AD 100">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=LITCW-AD%20100">
          LITCW-AD 100 Literary Interpretation
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course introduces students to the demands and pleasures of university-level investigation of literature. Students develop the tools necessary for advanced criticism, including close-reading skills, knowledge of generic conventions, mastery of critical terminology, and introduction to a variety of modes of analysis, from the formal to the historical. The course emphasizes the writing and revision strategies necessary to produce sophisticated literary analysis.
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Students in the NYUNY English Dept: This course is equivalent to
           </em>
           <em>
            ENGL-UA 200 Literary Interpretation.
           </em>
          </p>
         </div>

          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2013
           </span>

           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="LITCW-AD 101">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=LITCW-AD%20101">
          LITCW-AD 101 Major Texts in Critical Theory
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Major texts in critical theory from Plato to Derrida are considered in relation to literary practice. The first half of the course focuses on four major types of critical theory: mimetic, ethical, expressive, and formalist. The second half turns to 20th-century critical schools, such as Russian and American formalism, archetypal criticism, structuralism, psychoanalytic criticism, feminism, reader-response theory, deconstruction, and historicism.
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Students in the NYUNY English Dept: This course is equivalent to
           </em>
           <em>
            ENGL-UA 712 Major Texts in Critical Theory.
           </em>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2012
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/wolfgang-neuber.html">
             Wolfgang Neuber
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             MW, 2:35-3:50
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="121">
            Literature
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="13">

           </span>
          </li>

          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="LITCW-AD 103">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=LITCW-AD%20103">
          LITCW-AD 103 Foundations of Literature I: Epic and Drama
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course introduces students to two major genres of literature—epic and drama—and to fundamental terms and critical methods employed by literary scholars. Topics to be investigated include: the relationship between text and context, close vs. distant reading, the nature of authorship; genre; the interplay of local, national, regional, and world modes of categorization; translation; book history; and the relationship between literature and other forms of art. Each unit of the course is constructed around an anchoring text or texts that will be contextualized both historically and generically through a wide range of primary and secondary readings. For fall 2014, the anchoring texts are Ferdowsi’s The Shahnameh, Virgil’s The Aeneid, and Sophocles’ Oedipus the King.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2013
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/cyrus-r-k--patell.html">
             Cyrus R.K. Patell
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             MW, 9:55-11:10 AM
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2014
           </span>
           ;

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="LITCW-AD 104">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=LITCW-AD%20104">
          LITCW-AD 104 Foundations of Literature II: Lyric Poetry and the Novel
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course introduces students to two major genres of literature—lyric poetry and the novel —and to fundamental terms and critical methods employed by literary scholars. Topics to be investigated include: the relationship between text and context; close vs. distant reading; the nature of authorship, genre, the interplay of local, national, regional, and world modes of categorization; translation, book history, and the relationship between literature and other forms of art. Each unit of the course is constructed around an anchoring text or texts that will be contextualized both historically and generically through a wide range of primary and secondary readings. For fall 2014, the anchoring texts are Wordsworth and Coleridge’s Lyrical Ballads and Melville’s Moby-Dick; for spring 2015 they are Arabic and Persian ghazals and Austen's Pride and Prejudice.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2014
           </span>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="LITCW-AD 105">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=LITCW-AD%20105">
          LITCW-AD 105 Problems and Methods of Literary Studies
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course develops students’ understanding of the central questions and problems that drive literary studies. Drawing upon a long history of theoretical approaches, the course considers such questions as: What is literature? What is a text? What does a literary critic or scholar do? What does it mean to read literature in translation? How does language shape meaning? How do we construct meaning from a text—and why does that meaning matter? And, crucially: what is at stake in why we ask and how we answer these questions? This class will engage these questions by reading widely, from primary theoretical and critical texts to examples from print and digital material, and by exploring particular practices of literary scholarship—from archival research to work in digital humanities—that offer necessary skills for effective critical practice.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2014
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>

           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/katherine-williams.html">
             Katherine Williams
            </a>
            -

             TR, 3:35-4:50 pm
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">

            14 Weeks

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="LITCW-AD 106">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=LITCW-AD%20106">
          LITCW-AD 106 Humanism
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Humanism—which in some regions coincides with Renaissance—was a cultural movement initiated in Italy in the 14th century, spreading all over Europe until it reached its end in the 17th century. Its programmatic energy derived from the desire to remember something that seemed to have been obliterated and forgotten in the course of the Middle Ages, i.e. pagan antiquity. Basing their European—national and transnational—identities on something much older than Christianity, scholars (poets, painters, architects, composers, and philosophers) revived and developed scientifically the Greek and Roman legacy and laid the founding stones for Enlightenment and Modernity.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2013
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/wolfgang-neuber.html">
             Wolfgang Neuber
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             TR, 2:35-3:50
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="121">
            Literature
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="13">
            Literature and Creative Writing
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="10016">
            Literature Electives
           </span>
          </li>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="LITCW-AD 107X">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=LITCW-AD%20107X">
          LITCW-AD 107X The Postcolonial Turn
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           In postcolonial literature, representation and revolution intersect, as writers reinvent literary forms and seek to reconceive colonialism, nationalism, and modernity. The course compares British, Caribbean, Latin American, South Asian, and African texts, including travelogues, whose maps envision fantasies of the other; adaptations and translations of novels, in which mimicry and magical realism reveal how “the Empire writes back”; and memoirs and short stories, whose fragmentary and experimental forms express how memories of violence, displacement, and exile shape individuals today.
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Students in the NYUNY Comparative Literature Dept: This course counts for Comparative Literature elective credit or for the Literary and Cultural Studies Track
           </em>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2011
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="LITCW-AD 108">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=LITCW-AD%20108">
          LITCW-AD 108 Global Traffic: Fictions and Films of Place and Space
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Globalization, the acceleration of transportation and information technologies, transforms the experience of distance, producing perceptions of proximity and inter-connectedness across nations. It foregrounds movement and simultaneity, blurring boundaries between “real” and “virtual” worlds. Through texts emphasizing home, homelessness, migration, diaspora, transnationalism, tourism, the course examines how literature, film, games, graphic novels, and new media guide readers in this new landscape by charting new concepts of space and place, community, and global citizenship.
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Students in the NYUNY Comparative Literature Dept: This course counts for Comparative Literature elective credit or for the Literary and Cultural Studies Track
           </em>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2011
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="LITCW-AD 110">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=LITCW-AD%20110">
          LITCW-AD 110 Introduction to Creative Writing
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This workshop introduces the basic elements of poetry, fiction, and personal narrative with in-class writing, take-home reading and writing assignments, and substantive discussions of craft. The course is structured as a workshop, which means that students receive feedback from their instructor and their fellow writers in a roundtable setting, and they should be prepared to offer their classmates responses to their work.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="LITCW-AD 111">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=LITCW-AD%20111">
          LITCW-AD 111 Classical Literature and Its Global Reception
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           An introduction to three genres of literature from the ancient Greco-Roman world—drama, epic, and lyric poetry—together with an investigation of their continuing impact on the modern world.
          </p>
          <p>
           <em style="line-height:1.6em">
            For the NYUNY Classics Dept: This course counts for Classics literature elective credit
           </em>
          </p>
          <p>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="121">
            Literature
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="3">
            Multidisciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="31">
            The Ancient World
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="13">
            Literature and Creative Writing
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="10016">
            Literature Electives
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="LITCW-AD 113">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=LITCW-AD%20113">
          LITCW-AD 113 European Literary Traditions: Mysterious Adventures, Uncanny Encounters
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course presents a comparative approach to the formation and development of European literary traditions from the late eighteenth century to the present day, with an emphasis on fiction and poetry as embodiments of modernity. We will explore the ways in which authors reflect on their experience of modernity with stories that present mysterious situations, uncanny encounters, and events that defy rationality. Their texts present a discomfort with a reality that is experienced as modern and, therefore, discomforting and threatening. Particular attention will be paid to the specific national and historical setting of each text. This course functions as both an introduction to post-Enlightenment European literature and an in-depth study of the concept of modernity. We will be discussing the following texts, among others: Brothers Grimm, “Bluebeard;” Coleridge, “The Rime of the Ancient Mariner;” Hoffmann, “The Sandman;” Baudelaire,
           <em>
            Flowers of Evil
           </em>
           ; Dostoyevsky,
           <em>
            Notes from Underground
           </em>
           ; Stoker,
           <em>
            Dracula
           </em>
           ; Kafka,
           <em>
            The Metamorphosis;
           </em>
           and Saramago
           <em>
            , The Stone Raft
           </em>
           .
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2014
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/stephanie-hilger.html">
             Stephanie Hilger
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             MW, 8:15-9:30 am
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="LITCW-AD 114">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=LITCW-AD%20114">
          LITCW-AD 114 Global Women Writing
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Selected readings in poetry and fiction provide the focus for an exploration of representations of gender as they intersect class, race, nation, and sexuality. Readings are drawn from one or more regional traditions: Britain and northern Europe; the Mediterranean World; Africa and the African diaspora; Russia; the Middle East; South Asia; the Far East; and the Americas.
          </p>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="LITCW-AD 115">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=LITCW-AD%20115">
          LITCW-AD 115 History and Theory of the Novel
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           An introduction to the history of the novel in a comparative context, with special emphasis on contemporary critical theory (including circulation studies, deconstruction, new historicism, and psychoanalysis). Theoretical readings include works by Bakhtin, Barthes, Lukacs, McKeon, Moretti, and Watt, among others.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>

           This course appears in...

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="LITCW-AD 116">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=LITCW-AD%20116">
          LITCW-AD 116 History of Drama and Theater
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Examines selected plays central to the development of world drama, with critical emphasis on a cultural, historical, and theatrical analysis of these works. Texts are drawn from the major periods of Greek and Roman drama; Japanese classical theater; medieval drama; theater of the English, Italian, and Spanish Renaissance; French neoclassical drama; English Restoration and 18th-century comedy; and Russian dramatic traditions. Styles to be considered include romanticism, naturalism, realism, antirealism, and postcolonial theater.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="LITCW-AD 118">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=LITCW-AD%20118">
          LITCW-AD 118 Literary Translation
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course explores the craft of and the market for literary translation. Why do some translators aim for familiarity and others for estrangement? What is gained and lost in a text’s cultural relocation? Translation, and translation projects such as Abu Dhabi’s Kalima, play a pivotal role in shaping intercultural exchange and globalizing literary markets and canons. The course involves conversations with translators and authors in Abu Dhabi and abroad. Case studies include The Epic of Gilgamesh, the quatrains of Khayyam, sonnets of Shakespeare and Camões, and modern and contemporary works by Borges, Pessoa, Saramago, Kundera, Ondaatje, and Paz Soldan.
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Students NYUNY: This course counts for Expressive Culture (College Core) credit; For the NYUNY Comparative Literature Dept: This course counts for Comparative Literature elective credit or for the Literary and Cultural Studies Track
           </em>
          </p>
          <p>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="121">
            Literature
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="13">
            Literature and Creative Writing
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="10016">
            Literature Electives
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>

          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
