        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="MDENV-AD 110">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=MDENV-AD%20110">
          MDENV-AD 110 The Biosphere
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course introduces students to the fundamental dynamics of Earth’s atmosphere and its oceans. These two systems are then integrated into a global picture of the biosphere. Topics include: the carbon cycle, climate feedbacks and anthropogenic influences; global ecology, energy transport, the paleoclimate record, the coupled atmosphereocean-ice-land system, and climate modeling. The course addresses local and global issues such as desertification, carbon production by fossil fuels, and green technology as exemplified in Abu Dhabi’s Masdar City, which is attempting to become the world’s first carbonneutral, zero-waste city.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="3">
            Multidisciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="33">
            The Environment
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="MDENV-AD 111">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=MDENV-AD%20111">
          MDENV-AD 111 Global Climate Change
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           In this seminar students delve more deeply into the models and data that are the basis for our current understanding of Earth’s climate, and how it is changing. The course weaves quantitative analysis with human impacts, economics, and policy-making.
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Students in the NYUNY Environmental Studies Dept: This course counts for an Environmental Studies 300-level science elective.
           </em>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2 2014

           <span class="duration">

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="MDENV-AD 112">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=MDENV-AD%20112">
          MDENV-AD 112 Energy and the Environment
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Economic analysis of major policy issues in energy and the environment, both domestic and international, is key for understanding the global impact of energy use. This course emphasizes market solutions to various problems and market limitations in the allocation of environmental resources. Energy issues focus on OPEC and world oil markets; taxation and regulation of production and consumption; conservation of natural resources; and the transition to alternative energy sources. Environmental issues include policies to reduce pollution. Substantial attention is paid to global warming caused by consumption of fossil fuels.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="3">
            Multidisciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="33">
            The Environment
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="3">
            Multidisciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="33">
            The Environment
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="94">
            Courses in Environmental Policy
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>

         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="MDENV-AD 113">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=MDENV-AD%20113">
          MDENV-AD 113 Environment and Society
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           A systematic survey of central concepts and issues relating to environment and society including environmental history and concepts of nature and the environment; the rise of environmentalism; environmental skepticism; anthropogenic global change; population and consumption, ecological footprint analysis, and other environmental indicators; environmental justice; and regulatory regimes.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="3">
            Multidisciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="33">
            The Environment
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="3">
            Multidisciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="33">
            The Environment
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="94">
            Courses in Environmental Policy
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="MDENV-AD 115">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=MDENV-AD%20115">
          MDENV-AD 115 The Global Debate on Green Growth
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           In March 2012, the OECD published its influential Environmental Outlook Report to 2050, confirming that the world is faced with an explosive new cocktail of geopolitical challenges: population explosion, environmental degradation, the failure to stop climate change, and the increased competition over limited natural resources.  In response, governments are increasingly turning to renewables and high tech to diversify their energy mix and to reduce reliance on fossil fuels in order to stimulate stagnant economies and create new jobs. Ironically, the transition to a low fossil fuel economy through the use of RES and high tech applications has led to the creation of new global race over limited resources, such as rare earths, and this competition has already given rise to a series of fresh global political and economic realities, tensions, and disputes.  We will examine how major industrial powers are approaching  the asymmetric threat of climate change; the nature of contemporary resource competition; the way policy decisions are influenced by political rhetoric and public opinion; and the overall economic and political impact of climate change on international relations.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2014
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/sophia-kalantzakos.html">
             Sophia Kalantzakos
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             TR, 2:10-3:25 pm
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="3">
            Multidisciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="33">
            The Environment
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="3">
            Multidisciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="33">
            The Environment
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="95">
            Courses in Environment, Culture and Society
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>

          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>

       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="MDMED-AD 101">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=MDMED-AD%20101">
          MDMED-AD 101 Introduction to Interactive Media
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           With the advent of digital computation, humans have found a variety of new tools for self expression and communication. By approaching software and electronics as artists and designers, we can explore new paradigms of interaction with machines and each other. This introductory course will provide students hands-on experience with screen-based and physical interaction design through programming and circuit building.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2014
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/scott-fitzgerald.html">
             Scott Fitzgerald
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             T, 12:45-2:00 pm; R 12:45-3:15 pm
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>

          </strong>

            Art and Art History: Arts Practice
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="MDMED-AD 102">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=MDMED-AD%20102">
          MDMED-AD 102 Communications Lab
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           A production based course that surveys various technologies including digital imaging, video, audio, animation, and basic web development. The forms and uses of new communications technologies are explored in a laboratory context of experimentation and discussion. Principles of interpersonal communications and media theory are considered in this new context.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="MDMED-AD 110">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=MDMED-AD%20110">
          MDMED-AD 110 Applications of Media
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This class strives to create media literacy by asking students to study the history, theory, and practice of creating, distributing, and consuming media. What is media’s role in creating culture, influencing political events, forming communities, and archiving? What is ubiquitous computing, embedded computing, physical computing? How is cyberspace merging with physical space and how does participatory media change the face of cultural institutions, historical narratives, and mapping? Students are asked to consider the role of media in their own lives and consider where it both fails and succeeds.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2013
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/mo-ogrodnik.html">
             Mo Ogrodnik
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             T, 1:10-2:25 PM ; R 1:10-3:50 PM
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>

           This course appears in...
          </strong>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="MDMED-AD 111">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=MDMED-AD%20111">
          MDMED-AD 111 Mobile Media
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Mobile devices (phones and tablets) are used for both the production and consumption of rich media, augmenting their original purpose as one-to-one communication devices. This course explores the technology that enables the consumption and production of new forms of media on these devices with an eye toward how that media can be used in conjunction with the devices’ original social and communicative purposes. Students create projects that utilize the available technology to explore new forms of media creation and consumption.
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Students in the NYUNY ITP Dept: This course is equivalent to ITPG-GT 2690 Mobile Media
           </em>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2012
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="MDMED-AD 112">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=MDMED-AD%20112">
          MDMED-AD 112 Introduction to Physical Computing
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           What can computation add to human communication? This course focuses on the fundamentals of computer programming and how you can make it interact with the physical world. Students write very simple programs to sense physical switches and control LED lights. The course is designed for computer programming novices.
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Pre-requisite - Applications of Media (MDMED-AD 110) may be taken concurrently.
           </em>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="prerequisites">
          <li>
           Applications of Media
          </li>
         </ul>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="MDMED-AD 113">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=MDMED-AD%20113">
          MDMED-AD 113 Networked Objects
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course explores the possibilities and challenges of designing alternate physical network interfaces. This class covers methods for making interfaces talk to each other.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...

          There are no prerequisites for this course.

       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="MDMED-AD 114J">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=MDMED-AD%20114J">
          MDMED-AD 114J Values in Information Technology and Digital Media
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Computing, information technology, and digital media are integrated into all aspects of contemporary life including commerce, finance, education, politics, entertainment, communication, and social life. This course studies these technologies through the lens of social, political, and ethical values investigating whether and how technical systems promote or impede values to which we are committed. While we explore concepts and literatures, students form collaborative groups, select projects and apply philosophical and social theories of technology to analyze and, possibly, design, prototype, and build systems. The course welcomes students with a variety of backgrounds and skills, though some prior understanding of and experience with digital technology and media, and computing or social, political, and ethical analysis is recommended.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            January 2014
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            Helen F. Nissenbaum
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="MDMED-AD 115">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=MDMED-AD%20115">
          MDMED-AD 115 New Interfaces of Musical Expression
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course approaches questions such as "What is performance?", "What  makes a musical interface intuitive and emotionally immediate?", and "How do we create meaningful correlations between performance gestures and their musical consequences?" Over the semester, we look at many examples of current work by creators of musical interfaces, and discuss a wide range of issues facing technology-enabled performance. Students will design and prototype a musical instrument - a complete system encompassing musical controller, algorithm for mapping input to sound, and the sound output itself. A technical framework for  prototyping performance controllers is made available. Students focus on musical composition and improvisation techniques as they prepare their prototypes for live performance.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="3">
            Multidisciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="34">
            Interactive Media and Technology
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="14">
            Music
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="14">
            Music
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="176">
            Artistic Practice Track
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="14">
            Music
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="177">
            Music Studies Track
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">

           </span>

          There are no prerequisites for this course.

       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="MDMED-AD 116">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=MDMED-AD%20116">
          MDMED-AD 116 Mashups - Creating with Web APIs
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           As the World Wide Web continues to grow and pervade our everyday lives, an ever-increasing amount of data and digital services are becoming accessible to us through public web APIs - Application Programming Interfaces. Common to many web sites, including YouTube, Twitter, Google Maps, Wikipedia and more, these web APIs offer a way to programmatically request and re-purpose endless troves of information. How might we use these available resources to create unique, creative, and compelling web experiences of our own? Subscribing to a process-oriented approach, much of class time will be spent reviewing and writing code, primarily Javascript, for client-side (front-end) web development.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2014
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/craig-protzel.html">
             Craig Protzel
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             T, 9:15-11:55 am; R 9:15-10:30 am
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
         </ul>

          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="MDMED-AD 202">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=MDMED-AD%20202">
          MDMED-AD 202 Experiential Video Art
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           The advent of video heralded a new, mediated form of expression, quickly embraced by artists, journalists, and provocateurs. This course provides an overview of video art since its inception in the late 1960s and is designed to trace the path of the medium to contemporary practices. Emerging methods of video interaction in the context of performance and installation will be applied. Students will develop their own work while examining technical and aesthetic concepts embedded in existing pieces.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2015
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/scott-fitzgerald.html">
             Scott Fitzgerald
            </a>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>

            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">

            Film and New Media
           </span>

        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           An introductory course designed to provide students with hands-on experience using various technologies for web design and development, online audio, video and animation, mobile web, and physical computing. The forms and uses of new communications technologies are explored in a laboratory context of experimentation and discussion. Principles of interpersonal communications, media theory, and human factors are introduced.

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="MDURB-AD 114">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=MDURB-AD%20114">
          MDURB-AD 114 Planning Abu Dhabi
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Abu Dhabi, with its urban plan for the future, Plan Abu Dhabi 2030, has globally positioned itself as a progressive laboratory of urbanism. The course provides an immersion in the planning issues that Abu Dhabi confronts and that are central to the future of the 21st-century city. We read key texts in urban theory and design, and consider their applicability to the city’s specific context and morphology. The course includes field trips to key projects and feature guest speakers who are defining the future of the city. By the end of the course, students have in-depth knowledge of Abu Dhabi, its urban form, future goals, and challenges; think critically about successful city building with a comparative approach to experiences elsewhere.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="MDURB-AD 114J">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=MDURB-AD%20114J">
          MDURB-AD 114J Planning Abu Dhabi
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           As Abu Dhabi strives to position itself as a global capital city, it has embarked on ambitious plans for urban, economic and social development. Since 2007, Plan Capital 2030 laid the foundation for a progressive and comprehensive approach with sustainability as an overarching principle. The course will introduce a full understanding of the evolution of the city, examine plans for Abu Dhabi, and learn about the main urban actors and the forces shaping its growth. Through reading key texts in urban theories, site visits, guest speakers, presentations and debates, students will be able to think critically about city planning and development in rapidly developing cities and key challenges in comparison to other regional and global examples.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            January 2015
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="MDURB-AD 115">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=MDURB-AD%20115">
          MDURB-AD 115 New York and Modernity
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Modernism was a broad movement in literature, arts, music, and architecture that flourished first in Europe and then the United States between from the turn into the twentieth century until just after the Second World War. This course examines the ways in which New Yorkers reshaped European modernism and created a distinctive legacy that marks the city to this day. Exploring the reciprocal relationship between modernism and the city, the course investigates how modernism was shaped by urban experience and how, in turn, modernism helped to mold our conception of the modern city.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="MDURB-AD 115J">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=MDURB-AD%20115J">
          MDURB-AD 115J New York and Modernity
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Modernism was a broad movement in literature, arts, music, and architecture that flourished first in Europe and then the United States between from the turn into the twentieth century until just after the Second World War. This course examines the ways in which New Yorkers reshaped European modernism and created a distinctive legacy that marks the city to this day. Exploring the reciprocal relationship between modernism and the city, the course investigates how modernism was shaped by urban experience and how, in turn, modernism helped to mold our conception of the modern city.

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="MDURB-AD 116J">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=MDURB-AD%20116J">
          MDURB-AD 116J Metropolis: Culture and Politics in the 21st Century
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course provides an overview of key issues in the culture and politics of urban life, with a focus on modern Buenos Aires. We engage class and contemporary urban questions such as: How does city-living shape our minds and shift our patterns of social interaction? How does the built environment relate to the local ecology and our experience of everyday life? How are civic and political institutions addressing emerging problems related to massive population growth, sprawl, pollution, and polarization? Students should be prepared for rigorous critical thinking and vigorous participation.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            January 2013
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="MDURB-AD 117J">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=MDURB-AD%20117J">
          MDURB-AD 117J Post-Catastrophe Reconstruction
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Emergency response situations, such as natural disasters and terrorist attacks, are unfortunate but recurring events that have a major impact on today’s global society. This course explores the variety of complex issues surrounding post-catastrophe reconstruction (PCR) and provides an understanding of the process and players in emergency response situations as well as a critical historical analysis of previous reconstruction efforts. The class includes a field trip to Sri Lanka where students have an opportunity to experience first-hand and gain an understanding of a post-catastrophe area. In addition, students have the opportunity to meet with NGOs and government officials involved in the humanitarian as well as reconstruction effort. This course includes a field trip to Sri Lanka.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="3">
            Multidisciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="35">
            Urbanization
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>

          </strong>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="MDURB-AD 118">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=MDURB-AD%20118">
          MDURB-AD 118 Middle Eastern Cities: Urbanization and Society
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course investigates urbanization in the Middle East from early Islam to the modern period. It examines medieval and premodern cities as centers of religious and political authority and crucibles of commercial and cultural exchange, and investigates the challenges of modernity and westernization on these cities and their current adaptation to globalism. The course emphasizes Baghdad, Cairo, Damascus, Isfahan, and Istanbul.
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Students in the NYUNY MEIS Dept: This course counts towards MEIS history requirement
           </em>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="MDURB-AD 119">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=MDURB-AD%20119">
          MDURB-AD 119 Sustainable Cities in a Comparative Perspective
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course examines the social, economic, and environmental dimensions of sustainability in cities—in the current context of development and environmental challenges. Policies and programs that try to address the challenges of sustainability (from both developed and developing countries) are studied and compared.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
         </ul>

           Prerequisites
          </strong>

         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="MDURB-AD 120">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=MDURB-AD%20120">
          MDURB-AD 120 Urban Infrastructure in the 19th &amp; 20th Century
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           The world’s urban population is anticipated to reach 5 billion by 2030. The rise of mega-cities has captured much attention, however most of the world’s urban growth will take place in small to mid-size cities. To some extent, this is a desirable trend as smaller urban environments and utopian models of urban development. This course is a comparative study of the evolution of 19th and 20th century urban infrastructure. It examines the designs of complex infrastructure networks for moving people, goods, water, waste, energy, and information: from pipelines to the telecommunication network, from sidewalks to freeways and ports, and from personal carriers to mass transit.  In this course students develop a perspective on how the growth of urban population in first half of 19th century led to innovations in the second half of the century that sustained the tremendous growth of 19th century urban population; and how this trend continued to support that growth in the 20th century urban population. Each student will select a city and research the evolution of the various layers of that city’s infrastructure. The student “Cities Project” will be presented in the form of maps, photos, videos, interviews, stories.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="3">
            Multidisciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="35">
            Urbanization
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>

         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="MDURB-AD 121">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=MDURB-AD%20121">
          MDURB-AD 121 Urban Life and Cities in a Global Context
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course introduces students to the life of cities, their creation and development over time, and the effect of cities on the lives of people. Drawing on diverse disciplines, such as sociology, history, geography, and political science, it explores the process of urbanization, focusing on major theories of urbanization, the urban way of life, and problems related to the urbanization process. It also places these urban processes within a transnational and global context.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="3">
            Multidisciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="35">
            Urbanization
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="MDURB-AD 122J">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=MDURB-AD%20122J">
          MDURB-AD 122J Cities and Consumption
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Consumption of objects, images, and places is central to the culture and economy of modern life. The class addresses three questions: Why do we want things? How do physical places organize our consumer desires? And how does place become an object of consumption? This class explores how the relationship between consumption and cities has developed by examining three key moments: world fairs and the invention of the department store in the late nineteenth century; the rise of malls in the mid-20th century and the contemporary period of digital commerce and the global commodity city. Readings include Thorstein Veblen’s Theory of the Leisure Class, Karl Marx’s essay on commodity fetishism, Max Weber’s essays on economy and society, Georg Simmel’s Metropolis and Mental Life and selections from Walter Benjamin’s Arcades project. We relate these texts to changing forms of consumption in different settings, from Argentina to China and the United States. Site visits in Buenos Aires help deepen our analysis of cities and consumption, and illuminate our surroundings.
          </p>
          <p>
          </p>
          <p>
          </p>
          <p>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            January 2013

             Caitlin Zaloom
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             T, BD
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Buenos Aires, Argentina
            </em>
           </span>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="MDURB-AD 123J">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=MDURB-AD%20123J">
          MDURB-AD 123J Nature of Urban Design: a New York Perspective on Resilience
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course is an introduction to the role of urban design in global sustainability. The first step is to understand how cities affect climate and how climate affects cities by examining New York as a model. New York is a coastal city faced with the simultaneous requirement to grow its population by a million people yet to improve the quality of its civic life when climate events threaten both its urban fabric and critical infrastructure. How New York uses urban design not just to survive but to thrive is the subject of this course, introducing the people, products, and processes of urban design. The city itself frequently serves as classroom, with students exploring and recording examples of urban design through the neighborhoods they transform.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            January 2014
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            Alexandros Washburn
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             New York City
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="3">
            Multidisciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="35">
            Urbanization
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="MDURB-AD 124J">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=MDURB-AD%20124J">
          MDURB-AD 124J Urban Form of Shanghai
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Shanghai has evolved markedly through key stages in the history of urban form, vestiges of which are found within the city today: an old walled "Chinese city"; tree-lined boulevards and commercial avenues of 19th and 20th century foreign settlements; and suburban development in Pudong. This class examines each key stage, combining readings with in situ urban inquiry. Readings cover Chinese reflections on the city in general and Shanghai in particular, as well as urban studies classics like Lewis Mumford’s The Culture of Cities Trips take students to historically significant cultural spaces, including the old City God Temple, Fuzhou Road Bookshops, alleyway houses, The Peace Hotel, the Great World amusement park, People’s Park, the Moganshan Road contemporary art complex, as well as nearby waterway towns that illustrate aspects of Shanghai’s history before urbanization.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            January 2014
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/mark-swislocki.html">
             Mark Swislocki
            </a>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Shanghai, China
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="120">
            History
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="3">
            Multidisciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="35">
            Urbanization
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="12">
            History
           </span>
           &gt;

           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="MDURB-AD 125J">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=MDURB-AD%20125J">
          MDURB-AD 125J Global City
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Cities are our most powerful engines of growth and increasingly the economic organizing units of our time. More than half the world’s population lives in cities and urban areas, a figure that grow to 70 percent by 2050. We will look in detail at great global cities across the world, giving students the concepts and tools to understand their evolution and the critical roles they play in economic, social, cultural and human development. The course also helps students better understand how their choice of a city to live in can have an indelible impact on their lives and careers.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            January 2013
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            Richard Florida
								
								
								
									 -
            <span class="schedule">
             T, BD
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            January 2014
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            Richard Florida
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="3">
            Multidisciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="35">
            Urbanization
           </span>
          </li>

          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>

          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="MDURB-AD 126J">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=MDURB-AD%20126J">
          MDURB-AD 126J Cities, Nations, and Globalization
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           What is globalization and when did it begin? What is the difference between an imperial city and a global capital? Imperial London provides a way to explore this question, and New York, which was not capital of a vast colonial empire, provides a useful comparison case. There is also the question of globalization’s impact on the relation between cities and nations? More directly, have global cities outgrown their host nations? Is globalization a new iteration of the world economy, or is it more multi-faceted, with social, political, and cultural implications, including new dimensions of citizenship and social movements? Can one "read" shift from the age of empire to that of globalization in the built environment of the city of London, New York, Jakarta, or Ho Chi Minh City? Assignments includes literary sources and visual analysis as well as social science and humanistic scholarship.
          </p>
          <p>
           <em style="line-height:1.6em">
            *Note: Students in the NYUNY Metropolitan Studies Dept: This course counts for the major and minor
           </em>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            January 2014
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/tom-bender.html">
             Tom Bender
            </a>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             London, England
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="3">
            Multidisciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="35">
            Urbanization
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="MDURB-AD 127J">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=MDURB-AD%20127J">
          MDURB-AD 127J Public Space and the Life of Cities
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Public spaces play an essential role in the life of cities and their residents. Public squares and parks, streets and esplanades—these are often the signature spaces that constitute a city’s distinctive identity. They are also the settings of everyday life, mixing bowls where a city’s diverse communities interact, forums for individual as well as collective action and expression. This course explores the nature of public space in cities around the world, with attention to their physical character and design, their history, their pictorial and literary representation, and the political and social practices that activate public space. We will explore three overarching questions. What do we mean by “public” and “public space”? What are common characteristics of public spaces and how do people use them? And why are public spaces important to city life? In addition to historical and contemporary squares and streetscapes of Europe and the Middle East, we will draw upon case studies in Sydney as well as the hometowns of our students.
          </p>
          <p>
           *For NYU New York and NYU Shanghai students interested in this course, please submit the
           <a href="http://nyuad.nyu.edu/en/academics/global-education/jterm-application-nyu.html">
            application
           </a>
           by October 15th. For more information about NYU Abu Dhabi courses being offered during January term visit our
           <a href="http://www.nyu.edu/admissions/january-term/nyu-abu-dhabi-january-term.html">
            website
           </a>
           .
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            January 2015
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">

            </a>

            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/mariet-westermann.html">
             Mariet Westermann
            </a>
            <br/>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="MUSIC-AD 100">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=MUSIC-AD%20100">
          MUSIC-AD 100 Music Theory Fundamentals
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course provides students with essential musical skills and conceptual frameworks that will ready them for future coursework in music theory.  These fundamentals are explored in relation not only to canonic Western "classical" music, but also to popular music and musics from around the globe. Topics include Western music notation (reading music), tuning systems, the science of sound, instruments, scales, modes, keys, intervals, chords, jazz/pop/rock chord symbols, figured bass, harmonic analysis using Roman numerals, species counterpoint, basic four-part chorale writing, and common forms and genres.  A weekly lab session serves to develop listening skills, basic keyboard skills, sight-singing, and dictation.
          </p>
          <p>
           <br/>
           Note: Music Theory Fundamentals is a prerequisite for the required music major gateway course, Music Theory &amp; Analysis I.  Students can take a placement test to pass out of Music Theory Fundamentals and enroll directly in Music Theory &amp; Analysis I. Please contact the instructor or Head of Music Program for details.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2015
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="MUSIC-AD 101">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=MUSIC-AD%20101">
          MUSIC-AD 101 Interpreting Music
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course introduces students to several modes of inquiry as it explores and introduces a wide repertoire of musical materials. We explore approaches to music, stressing historical, documentary, and archival work and contrast these with ethnographic, philosophical, and empirical/scientific modes of investigation. Repertoire varies from year to year, but includes such aspects as Beethoven symphonies, North Indian instrumental music, Middle Eastern song, and new technologies such as auto-tune and new arenas for music such as video games and ring tones.
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Students NYUNY: This course counts for Expressive Culture (College Core) credit; For the NYUNY Music Dept: This course counts for Music ethnomusicology elective credit
           </em>
          </p>
          <p>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2012

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="MUSIC-AD 105">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=MUSIC-AD%20105">
          MUSIC-AD 105 Music Theory &amp; Analysis I
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Required for all music majors.  This course views musical structures and constructs broadly, referencing phenomena from musics around the world. The bulk of the course is devoted to an exploration of melody, harmony, and counterpoint in the music of diatonic tonality through projects in directed composition and analysis. Repertoire is drawn from both “classical” (common practice period) music and more recent examples of tonality, including popular music. Regular reading and listening assignments place techniques in historical context and expose students to a wide range of musical examples. Weekly lab sections are devoted to skills in musicianship: listening, sight-singing, dictation, and basic keyboard skills.
          </p>
          <p>
           Prerequisite: Understanding of Western music notation (pitch and rhythm). Prerequisite is MUSIC-AD 100 or equivalent on placement test
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Students in the NYUNY Music Dept: This course is equivalent to MUSIC-UA 20
           </em>
           <em>
            Elements of Music; Students wishing to substitute MUSIC-AD 105 for MUSIC-UA 201 Harmony and Counterpoint 1 must sit a diagnostic exam in New York.
           </em>
          </p>
         </div>
         <p class="lab">
          This course has a
          <strong>
           laboratory component
          </strong>
          .
         </p>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="MUSIC-AD 106">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=MUSIC-AD%20106">
          MUSIC-AD 106 Music Technology Fundamentals
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Students will learn the basics of different aspects of music and technology.  This will include digital audio representation and formats, basics of studio and location recording, music communication protocols (MIDI and OSC), audio and MIDI sequencing using Live and Logic, and an introduction to Max. This course will also provide students with a base in elements of sonic design.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2014
           </span>

           <span class="duration">

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="MUSIC-AD 111">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=MUSIC-AD%20111">
          MUSIC-AD 111 Music of the Middle East and North Africa
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           The Near East (including North Africa, Turkey, Iran and the Gulf) has experienced enormous upheavals over the past century, in large part because of borders drawn by political rather than cultural considerations. Today's Levant, Maghreb and Gulf offer an enormous wealth of cultural diversity and local variation that a strictly political reading fails to recognize. Each year the course focuses on two different regions from among North Africa, the Levant, the Gulf, Turkey and Iran, in order to understand the complex socio-cultural dynamics of the broader region. Focusing on issues of gender, religion and nation, the course pays particular attention to the development of the Maqam system, ritual practices of religious minorities, and the popular musical styles that mobilize social movements.
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Students in the NYUNY MEIS Dept: This course counts for MEIS elective credit; For the NYUNY Music Dept: This course counts for Music ethnomusicology elective credit
           </em>
          </p>
          <p>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">

           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2013
           </span>

           <span class="duration">

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="MUSIC-AD 112">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=MUSIC-AD%20112">
          MUSIC-AD 112 Topics in Western Classical Music
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Rather than present stylistic overviews, this course focuses on selected works and introduces them in various contexts. Depending on the experience and expertise of the instructor, the course might focus on Bach fugues, Mozart opera, Schoenberg’s piano music, or the development of electro-acoustic music. While the focus is on issues of how these works create effects, and resultant questions of meaning, we also look at sociological and political issues.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2012
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/celina-charlier.html">
             Celina Charlier
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             MR, 2:35-3:50
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="157">
            Music
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="14">
            Music
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="91">
            History, Theory, Criticism
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="MUSIC-AD 120">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=MUSIC-AD%20120">
          MUSIC-AD 120 Making Music
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This practical course endeavors to expose students to the various processes and tools by which music is creatively conceived and brought to public life. Students of various skill sets gain the necessary footing to develop/envision themselves as music practitioners/makers in a changing global landscape, as we endeavor to focus on cosmopolitan music practices that draw on the uniqueness of the U.A.E. as a global site. Students work in teams to develop creative music projects involving original writing/composition, recording, and performance. They also develop a basic creative plan for dissemination that also involves emergent and/or interactive media. The course additionally has a historical scope in which students consider how aforementioned broad
           <br/>
           course questions have been addressed at different key moments in history and how the complexion of those questions has differed in various national and regional contexts.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2013
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/jason-king.html">
             Jason King
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             MW, 9:55-11:10 AM
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2014
           </span>

           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">

            </span>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="MUSIC-AD 171">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=MUSIC-AD%20171">
          MUSIC-AD 171 Group Music Instruction for Beginners
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           his course will focus on establishing a basic foundation at the instrument that will become the basis for developing a comfortable posture and beautiful tone.
           <br/>
           Basic musicianship will be explored through movement and singing games and note-reading introduced.
          </p>
          <p>
           Students should contact the instructor for further details and questions regarding enrollment.
          </p>
          <p>
           * Note: Counted for 1- 2 credits.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="MUSIC-AD 181-191">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=MUSIC-AD%20181-191">
          MUSIC-AD 181-191 Music Ensembles
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           A diverse array of vocal and instrumental ensembles is offered each semester. Participants develop skills in active musicianship: performance, listening, communication, and collaboration. Ensembles are offered at beginner, intermediate, and advanced performance levels. Please contact the instructor or Head of the Music Program for details.
          </p>
          <p>
           Music majors as well as non-music majors are encouraged to participate in small ensembles.
          </p>
          <p>
           For information regarding the Cello ensemble, contact Professor Gwyneth Bravo:
           <a href="mailto:gwyneth.bravo@nyu.edu" target="_blank">
            gwyneth.bravo@nyu.edu
           </a>
           .
          </p>
          <p>
           For information regarding the Klezmer Ensemble, contact Professor Walter Zev Feldman:
           <a href="mailto:wf10@nyu.edu" target="_blank">
            wf10@nyu.edu
           </a>
           .
          </p>
          <p>
           For information regarding all other instrumental and vocal duos, trios, quartets, quintets, larger ensembles, vocal ensemble and New Music ensemble, please contact Professor Celina Charlier:
           <a href="mailto:cbc213@nyu.edu" target="_blank">
            cbc213@nyu.edu
           </a>
           . Please note: Auditions for music ensemble classes with Professor Celina Charlier on Saturday, September 6th. Chamber music ensemble classes start on the second week of classes. Sign-up with approval by the instructor only.
          </p>
         </div>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="MUSIC-AD 192">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=MUSIC-AD%20192">
          MUSIC-AD 192 Private Instruction in Composition
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Private instruction in Composition is designed for students wanting to create musical work under supervision. This work can be for instruments, voice, electronics, or a combination of the three, for a variety of purposes, ranging from traditional concert music to music for film or for interactive computer applications such as games. Students learn compositional techniques and strategies that are tailored to help them achieve their compositional goals. The created work is presented in concert or at a similar public artistic manifestation.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2013
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>

            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/carlos-guedes.html">
             Carlos Guedes
            </a>
            <br/>

             Abu Dhabi

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="MUSIC-AD 193">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=MUSIC-AD%20193">
          MUSIC-AD 193 Private Instruction in Music Performance
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Private Instruction in Music Performance is designed for students willing to learn or develop their skills in performing an instrument. Acceptance to Private Instruction in Music Performance is subject to approval by the instructor.
          </p>
          <p>
           For Fall 2014: Auditions for chamber music ensembles and for flute instruction will be held on September 6th. Classes start the following week, and participation is by approval of the instructor only. For information about auditions, contact Professor Celina Charlier:
           <a href="mailto:cbc213@nyu.edu">
            cbc213@nyu.edu
           </a>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">

        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=MUSIC-AD%20198">
          MUSIC-AD 198 Directed Study
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Closely supervised individual research on a particular topic, undertaken by arrangement with an individual faculty member, resulting in a substantial paper.
           <br/>
           Offered by application Prerequisite: permission of the instructor.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="MUSIC-AD 205">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=MUSIC-AD%20205">
          MUSIC-AD 205 Music Theory &amp; Analysis II
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Further exploration of melody, harmony, and counterpoint in tonal music through projects in directed composition and analysis, transitioning into 20th-century and contemporary musical developments. Topics include small- and large-scale musical forms, modulation, mixture, chromaticism, and an array of modernist and post-modernist compositional practices.  A weekly lab session develops skills in musicianship and reinforces theoretical concepts.
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Students in the NYUNY Music Dept: This course is equivalent to MUSIC-UA 202
           </em>
           <em>
            Harmony and Counterpoint II.
           </em>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2013
           </span>

           <span class="duration">

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="MUSIC-AD 206">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=MUSIC-AD%20206">
          MUSIC-AD 206 Musics of the World: Approaches to Theory
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Techniques of analyzing Western “classical” tonal music are well codified, but investigating the workings of non-Western traditions demands creativity, research, and careful consideration of the practical and cultural perspectives. This course surveys a variety of musics, with a particular emphasis on careful listening and aural analysis. Assigned readings help to contextualize and problematize the listening, shedding light on musical preconceptions and biases. Each student chooses from a diverse array of research topics early in the semester, preparing for a substantial presentation during the final weeks of class.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2013
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/matthew-quayle.html">
             Matthew Quayle
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             TR, 2:35-3:50 PM
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2013
           </span>

           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="MUSIC-AD 210">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=MUSIC-AD%20210">
          MUSIC-AD 210 Producing and Recording Techniques
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course offers readings and practical experience with a broad array of musical technologies. Looking at everything from notational systems to musical instruments as machines, this course also focuses on the way contemporary developments from iPods to nanotechnologies are transforming the way we think about sound. Each year students develop a project involving hands-on use of new technologies and work with students in other areas of the Arts to execute it.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="157">
            Music
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="14">
            Music
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="90">
            Arts Practice
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="14">
            Music
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="177">
            Music Studies Track
           </span>

         </p>
