       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PHIL-AD 101">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHIL-AD%20101">
          PHIL-AD 101 Central Problems in Philosophy
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           An introduction to the discipline of philosophy by way of several central philosophical problems. Topics may include free will, the nature of the self, skepticism and the requirements for knowledge, the ethics of punishment, the existence of God, the requirements of justice, the relation between mind and body, and the nature of moral principles.
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Students in the NYUNY Philosophy Dept: This course is equivalent to PHIL-UA 1 Central Problems; counts for the minor requirement of one Introductory course in the subject
           </em>
          </p>
         </div>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PHIL-AD 111">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHIL-AD%20111">
          PHIL-AD 111 Minds and Machines
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           An introduction to philosophy through the study of issues at the intersection of philosophy and cognitive science. We will focus on the conflict between computational and biological approaches to understanding the mind. Topics will include whether a machine could think, the Turing Test, mental imagery, the possibility of artificial intelligence, the reduction of the mind to the brain, and the function of consciousness.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>

           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="123">
            Philosophy
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="15">
            Philosophy
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="127">
            Introductory Electives
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PHIL-AD 112">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHIL-AD%20112">
          PHIL-AD 112 Life and Death
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           We are all going to die. This course examines a number of puzzles that arise once we start to think about our mortality. Is death bad for us? How could it be, when we will no longer be around to be the subject of the harm? Is death any worse for us than our nonexistence was prior to our birth? Is it bad not to be born at all? If so, for whom is it bad? Are we, in some sense, immortal? Is immortality even desirable? What is the appropriate attitude toward death? Can suicide be moral or rational? Is there any sense in which we could survive our deaths? How should the knowledge that we are going to die affect the way we should live our lives?
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="123">
            Philosophy
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="15">
            Philosophy
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="127">
            Introductory Electives
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PHIL-AD 113">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHIL-AD%20113">
          PHIL-AD 113 Freedom and Responsibility
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Do we have free will? Can we think of ourselves as responsible agents while also regarding ourselves as part of the natural order? Some philosophers have argued that if our actions are causally determined, then freedom of the will is impossible. Others have argued that freedom does not depend on the truth or falsity of causal determinism. Is free will possible in a world where every event is causally determined? Are there different kinds of freedom? If so, are all kinds of freedom equally worth having? Must we act freely in order to be responsible for our actions? Do the social institutions of reward and punishment depend for their justification upon the existence of responsible, free agents? We will discuss the nature of persons, action, freedom, and responsibility in an effort to answer these questions.
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Students in the NYUNY Philosophy Dept: This course counts for a Philosophy elective.
           </em>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2012
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            Nishi Shah
								
								
								
									 -
            <span class="schedule">
             TR, 11:20-12:35
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="123">
            Philosophy
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PHIL-AD 116">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHIL-AD%20116">
          PHIL-AD 116 Reason and Religion
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           An examination of various questions that arise in philosophical discussions of religion, such as: Can philosophical reflection help us to prove the existence of God or clarify such puzzling matters as God's relationship to time? How could a benevolent and omnipotent God permit the existence of evil and misfortune? Is it ever rational to form beliefs about matters which transcend the realm of the empirical? Is the concept of a specifically religious experience a coherent one? If not, can religious beliefs be supported by other means? Alternatively, is the entire project of evaluating religious discourse as a set of claims about transcendent realities misguided? What should we make of the alternative explanations of religion and religious phenomena offered by philosophers from al-Farabi to Marx and Nietzsche?
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2014
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            Taneli Kukkonen
								
								
								
									 -
            <span class="schedule">
             TR, 12:45-2:00 pm
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">

           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="123">
            Philosophy

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PHIL-AD 118">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHIL-AD%20118">
          PHIL-AD 118 Fear of Knowledge
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           It is often thought that knowledge is inherently valuable and that "truth" is an objective notion independent of social considerations. This course examines various reasons we might have for holding these views, and various challenges that have been raised against them. Why should we care about knowledge as long as our beliefs prove useful and efficacious? Is truth -- and thus knowledge - more accurately understood as a culturally relative notion, so that what’s true for you might not be true for me? It is ever rational to let purely pragmatic reasons for belief trump considerations of truth? And could we ever will (or force) ourselves to believe something? These are some of the questions we’ll explore in this course.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2014
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/kevin-coffey.html">
             Kevin Coffey
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             MW, 9:55-11:10 AM
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>

           This course appears in...
          </strong>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PHIL-AD 145">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHIL-AD%20145">

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PHIL-AD 180">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHIL-AD%20180">
          PHIL-AD 180 Introduction to Logic
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           All philosophers are wise, and Socrates is a philosopher. Therefore, Socrates is wise. Our topic is the nature of this “therefore.” Logic is the science of reasoning—the study of the ways in which statements support or contradict one another. In this course, we investigate and expose the logical structure of everyday language and see how the correctness or incorrectness of reasoning depends on this structure. To aid us, we develop a formal language that makes this underlying structure more perspicuous. With this formal language at our disposal, we are able to construct elaborate proofs and explore the logical relations among the various steps of complex arguments.
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Students in the NYUNY Philosophy Dept: This course is equivalent to PHIL-UA 70–001 Logic; counts for the minor requirement in the subject
           </em>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2012
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/matthew-silverstein.html">
             Matthew Silverstein
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             UW, 11:20-12:35
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2014
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PHIL-AD 220">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHIL-AD%20220">
          PHIL-AD 220 Ancient Mediterranean Philosophy
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           An examination of the origins of Western philosophical thought in ancient Greece and Rome, with a special focus on the views of Plato and Aristotle. Through their work, we will grapple with a range of pressing philosophical questions, including: Is happiness more than a subjective state of consciousness? Is death harmful? Do we have free will? Do we have obligations to others that override the pursuit of our own self-interest? What is the relation between the mind (or the soul) and the body? Since most of the philosophers we will be studying thought that philosophy must be systematic in its approach, we will also try to evaluate the strengths and weaknesses of this kind of approach to philosophical questions.
          </p>
          <p>
           *Prerequiste: Introductory Elective in Philosophy (i.e., PHIL-AD 101-119).
          </p>
          <p>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2014
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/phil-mitsis.html">
             Phil Mitsis
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             MW, 9:15-10:30 am
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="123">
            Philosophy
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="3">
            Multidisciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="31">
            The Ancient World
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">

       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PHIL-AD 221X">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHIL-AD%20221X">
          PHIL-AD 221X Classical Arabic Philosophy
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           An introduction to the original continuation of Western philosophy in its post-ancient phase: Arabic philosophy in the form of falsafa, as developed and debated by Muslims, Christians, and Jews from the eighth to the twelfth century. The Arabic authors were heirs to the entire Greek philosophical legacy and took it in a number of important and innovative directions, some of which have remained with us to the present day. Topics broached include knowledge, certitude, and the rules of rational debate; the metaphysical distinction between essence and existence and the attendant notions of necessity and contingency; the medieval analysis of the soul, the psychic faculties, and moral psychology; and the role of religion in society and the analysis of religious claims within philosophy.
          </p>
          <p>
           *Prerequiste: Introductory Elective in Philosophy (i.e., PHIL-AD 101-119).
          </p>
          <p>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2015
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            Taneli Kukkonen
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="123">
            Philosophy
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="3">
            Multidisciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="31">
            The Ancient World
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="3">
            Multidisciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="32">
            The Arab Crossroads
           </span>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PHIL-AD 223">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHIL-AD%20223">
          PHIL-AD 223 Classical Indian Philosophy
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           An exploration of the thought of major philosophers from the Indian subcontinent, beginning with the ancients in the fifth century BCE and concluding with thinkers on the eve of colonialism in the eighteenth century CE. Indian philosophy has been and continues to be a major world philosophy. The reach of its ideas has been vast, both historically and geographically, spanning the philosophies of Buddhism, Jainism, Islam, and Hinduism, as well as the philosophy of law, of medicine, of mathematics, and of politics and society. It is most strongly associated with wide-ranging discussions in the philosophy of mind, the study of language, epistemology, and metaphysics. The aim of the course is to present a balanced and impartial picture of the richness, diversity, and depth of philosophy in this region.
          </p>
          <p>
           *Prerequiste: Introductory Elective in Philosophy (i.e., PHIL-AD 101-119).
          </p>
          <p>
          </p>
          <p>
          </p>
          <p>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>

            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="123">
            Philosophy
           </span>
          </li>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PHIL-AD 224">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHIL-AD%20224">
          PHIL-AD 224 Early Modern European Philosophy
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           A survey of European philosophy in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries—one of the most exciting and formative periods in the history of Western philosophy. We focus on six philosophers: René Descartes, Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz, John Locke, George Berkeley, David Hume, and Immanuel Kant. Through their writings, we trace and study philosophical arguments and debates concerning the possibility and extent of our knowledge of the external world, the nature of the self, the nature of substance and causation, the existence of God, the nature of perception, and the relation between our minds and our bodies.
          </p>
          <p>
           *Prerequiste: Introductory Elective in Philosophy (i.e., PHIL-AD 101-119).
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2013
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PHIL-AD 225">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHIL-AD%20225">
          PHIL-AD 225 Nineteenth- and Twentieth-Century European Philosophy
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           A survey of philosophy on the European continent in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries, beginning with German Idealism and proceeding through Marxism, existentialism, phenomenology, critical theory, and structuralism. This course will introduce you to many of the major thinkers of this period, including Hegel, Marx, Kierkegaard, Nietzsche, Husserl, Heidegger, Arendt, Sartre, Horkheimer, Adorno, and Foucault. These philosophers stand in the background of a great deal of contemporary political, social, and literary theory: their reactions to and criticisms of the Enlightenment’s celebration of reason continue to challenge us.
          </p>
          <p>
           *Prerequiste: Introductory Elective in Philosophy (i.e., PHIL-AD 101-119).
          </p>
          <p>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PHIL-AD 240">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHIL-AD%20240">
          PHIL-AD 240 Epistemology
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Epistemology is the study of knowledge and rational belief. In this course we examine various central epistemological questions, including: What is knowledge, and how does it differ from belief? Can we have knowledge of anything outside our own minds, such as physical objects or other minds? Or is the skeptic’s attack on our commonplace claims to know unanswerable? What is the relation between knowledge and perception? Is it ever rational to believe in the absence of evidence?
          </p>
          <p>
           *Prerequiste: Introductory Elective in Philosophy (i.e., PHIL-AD 101-119).
          </p>
          <p>
          </p>
          <p>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>

           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="123">
            Philosophy
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="15">
            Philosophy
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="53">
            Theoretical Philosophy
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PHIL-AD 241">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHIL-AD%20241">
          PHIL-AD 241 Metaphysics
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Metaphysics is the investigation of the nature of reality. In this course we wrestle with some of the most fundamental questions we are capable of posing, such as: What kinds of things exist? Are there minds or material bodies? What, for that matter, is existence? Is change illusory? What is truth? To what extent is reality independent of our thoughts about it? What is the difference between the possible and the actual? Are human actions free or causally determined? What is a person?
          </p>
          <p>
           *Prerequiste: Introductory Elective in Philosophy (i.e., PHIL-AD 101-119).
          </p>
          <p>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>

           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="123">
            Philosophy
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="15">
            Philosophy

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PHIL-AD 242">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHIL-AD%20242">
          PHIL-AD 242 Philosophy of Language
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           “Socrates was poisoned.” With those vocal sounds or marks on a page, I can make a claim about someone who lived in the distant past. How is that possible? How do our words manage to pick out or latch onto particular portions of reality, even ones with which we’ve never had any contact? How does language enable us to convey thoughts about everything from Abu Dhabi, to the hopes of a friend, to the stars beyond our galaxy? For that matter, what are the thoughts, or the meanings, that our words carry or communicate? We explore these and other philosophical questions about language through a reading of seminal works by twentieth-century thinkers.
          </p>
          <p>
           *Prerequiste: Introductory Elective in Philosophy (i.e., PHIL-AD 101-119).
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 1 2014
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            7 Weeks
           </span>

            </span>

            Philosophy

       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PHIL-AD 243">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHIL-AD%20243">
          PHIL-AD 243 Philosophy of Mind
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           What is the mind, and what can philosophy tell us about it? How is the mind related to the brain? Are they identical? How can we know when something has a mind? Could a machine have a mind? Could a machine be conscious? What, for that matter, is consciousness? Can consciousness be reconciled with a scientific view of the world? How do our mental states and attitudes, whatever they are, arise from activity in the brain and cause our actions? The rise of cognitive science has shed new light on many of these old questions. Can philosophers and cognitive scientists learn from each other even as they approach the study of the mind in their different ways? We examine various answers to these questions, drawing readings from classical and contemporary philosophy as well as from cognitive science.
          </p>
          <p>
           *Prerequiste: Introductory Elective in Philosophy (i.e., PHIL-AD 101-119).
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2015
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/jonardon-ganeri.html">
             Jonardon Ganeri
            </a>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="123">
            Philosophy
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="15">
            Philosophy
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="53">
            Theoretical Philosophy
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>

          </strong>

          </li>
         </ul>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PHIL-AD 244">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHIL-AD%20244">
          PHIL-AD 244 Philosophy of Science
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Science is often taken to be a distinctly rational form of empirical inquiry. This course examines various questions concerning the nature and practice of science that arise from this widespread attitude. For example, scientific theories are often thought to be subject to empirical scrutiny in ways that other theories are not. To what extent is this belief well-founded? Is it rational to believe that our best scientific theories are even approximately true? What justifies the claim that different types of evidence lend varying degrees of support to a particular theory, or that a single piece of evidence supports one theory more than another? Similarly, it is often claimed that scientific theories provide us with “real” explanations of physical phenomena, whereas other theories aren’t “genuinely explanatory.” To what extent is this true? What exactly is a scientific explanation, and how is it different (if at all) from a mere prediction or mathematical derivation? Can false theories provide good explanations? Some familiarity with science would be helpful but is not required.
          </p>
          <p>
           *Prerequiste: Introductory Elective in Philosophy (i.e., PHIL-AD 101-119).
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2014
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/kevin-coffey.html">
             Kevin Coffey
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             TR, 2:10-3:25 pm
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="123">
            Philosophy
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="15">
            Philosophy
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="53">
            Theoretical Philosophy
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>

       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PHIL-AD 260">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHIL-AD%20260">
          PHIL-AD 260 Ethics
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           What are our most basic values? What are the ethical principles by which we should judge our actions, ourselves, and our lives? What is involved in living a good human life? How can we reconcile the demands of morality with the personal obligations that spring from friendships and other relationships? Do the ends ever justify the means? We will grapple with these and other questions as we explore three of the most influential theories in Western ethical philosophy: Aristotle’s ethics of virtue, Immanuel Kant’s moral rationalism, and John Stuart Mill’s utilitarianism. We will also encounter one of modern morality’s harshest critics: Friedrich Nietzsche.
          </p>
          <p>
           *Prerequiste: Introductory Elective in Philosophy (i.e., PHIL-AD 101-119).
          </p>
          <p>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2013
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/matthew-silverstein.html">
             Matthew Silverstein
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             MW, 11:20-12:35 PM
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="123">
            Philosophy
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="15">
            Philosophy
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="52">
            Practical Philosophy
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="prerequisites">
          <li>
           Introductory Elective in Philosophy
          </li>
         </ul>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PHIL-AD 261">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHIL-AD%20261">
          PHIL-AD 261 Applied Ethics
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Torture, abortion, taxes, physician-assisted suicide, terrorism. People disagree fiercely about the morality of these and countless other human concerns. What moral theories and concepts shape these debates? Can we use these debates to refine or evaluate those theories and concepts?  Is it possible to find common ground in shared ethical principles that will allow us to engage in rational debates rather than in disrespectful shouting matches (or worse)? These will be our guiding question as we investigate many of the contemporary moral issues that divide us.
          </p>
          <p>
           *Prerequiste: Introductory Elective in Philosophy (i.e., PHIL-AD 101-119).
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="123">
            Philosophy
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="15">
            Philosophy
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="52">
            Practical Philosophy
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="prerequisites">
          <li>
           Introductory Elective in Philosophy
          </li>
         </ul>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PHIL-AD 262">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHIL-AD%20262">
          PHIL-AD 262 Medical Ehtics
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           An examinaton of the pressing moral questons that arise in medical practice and research. Do we have a basic right to health care? Are euthanasia and physician-assisted suicide ever morally permissible? Do we have the right to decide the course of our medical treatment, or to determine the timing and manner of our own deaths? Do we have a right to privacy and confidentiality? Should we allow medical research that harms animals (or that makes use of human stem cells)? Are there compelling moral objections to genetic testing or genetic engineering?
          </p>
          <p>
           *Prerequiste: Introductory Elective in Philosophy (i.e., PHIL-AD 101-119).
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="123">
            Philosophy
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="15">
            Philosophy
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="52">
            Practical Philosophy
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="prerequisites">
          <li>
           Introductory Elective in Philosophy
          </li>
         </ul>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PHIL-AD 263">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHIL-AD%20263">
          PHIL-AD 263 Aesthetics
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course addresses a number of questions that arise in philosophical discussions of the arts. What is art, and how do we evaluate it? Is there a standard of taste? Are there special aesthetic properties? Is there a special aesthetic attitude or a special aesthetic experience? Does it matter for the aesthetic value of a supposed work of art if it is a forgery? What is beauty, and how is it related to the sublime? What is the relation between aesthetic and moral values? Can there be great works of art that are morally bad? Why do we feel for fictional characters? Why do we enjoy horror films? How and what do pictures represent? How does music express emotions? What is it to give an ‘authentic’ performance of a piece of music? How does our aesthetic appreciation of art differ from our aesthetic appreciation of nature?
          </p>
          <p>
           *Prerequiste: Introductory Elective in Philosophy (i.e., PHIL-AD 101-119).
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="123">
            Philosophy
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="15">
            Philosophy
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="52">
            Practical Philosophy
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="prerequisites">
          <li>
           Introductory Elective in Philosophy
          </li>
         </ul>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PHIL-AD 264">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHIL-AD%20264">
          PHIL-AD 264 Political Philosophy
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           The state has authority over its citizens: if you fail to comply with its dictates, you can be punished. What justifies the state’s exercise of such authority? Could it be justified because we have at least implicitly given out consent to it? This is only one central question in political philosophy. Others include: What form of government best serves the people? Who are the people, anyway? What is justice? Do we have fundamental rights to property or to free expression? If so, what is the source of these rights? What is freedom, and are there different kinds? What is the proper relation between freedom and equality? Is equality desirable? Can we live in a genuine community that is not a community of equals? As we grapple with such questions, we draw on writings from both classical and contemporary philosophers.
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Students in the NYUNY Philosophy Dept: This course is equivalent to
           </em>
           <em>
            PHIL-UA 45 Political Philosophy; For the NYUNY Philosophy Dept: This course is equivalent to
           </em>
           <em>
            POL-GA 3100, 3101 Political Theory
           </em>
          </p>
          <p>
           *Prerequiste: Introductory Elective in Philosophy (i.e., PHIL-AD 101-119).
          </p>
          <p>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">

           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="123">
            Philosophy
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">

           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="124">
            Political Science
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PHIL-AD 280">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHIL-AD%20280">
          PHIL-AD 280 Advanced Logic
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           An advanced investigation of various aspects of symbolic logic and reasoning, with an emphasis on subjects of philosophical relevance. Specific topics vary by semester, but are generally drawn from the following: modal logic (the study of reasoning about necessity, possibility, counterfactuals, and tense); metalogic (the study of provability, completeness, and other higher-order properties of logical systems); nonclassical logic (the study of three-valued logical systems, free logics, and the logic of relevance); and mathematical logic (the study of logical systems intended to model arithmetic reasoning).
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="15">
            Philosophy
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="10017">
            Logic Courses
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="prerequisites">
          <li>
           Introduction to Logic
          </li>
         </ul>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PHIL-AD 320">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHIL-AD%20320">
          PHIL-AD 320 Topics in the History of Philosophy
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           An advanced seminar that involves the careful study of some particular movement, philosopher, or issue in the history of philosophy. Examples: German Idealism, Ibn Rushd, Kant, theories of causation in Indian philosophy, Aristotle.
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            *
           </em>
           Prerequistes: History of Philosophy, Theoretical Philosophy, or Practical Philosophy Elective (PHIL-AD 220-279).
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PHIL-AD 340">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHIL-AD%20340">
          PHIL-AD 340 Topics in Theoretical Philosophy
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           The world has more and less fundamental aspects. Quarks, bosons, and gravity are likely among the fundamental features. Cars, koalas, and coffees are not. The latter metaphysically depend on the former. The relation of metaphysical dependence, or ground, has applications in a wide variety of philosophical areas, from metaphysics to philosophy of mind to metaethics. For the most part, physics is in the business of discovering the fundamental features of reality. But debates about methodology in the search for the fundamental have rich philosophical dimensions. What is the nature of the relation of metaphysical dependence? Is it a genuinely explanatory notion? What are the rules of the game for positing relations of metaphysical dependence? When should we take some feature as fundamental? What role do our epistemic limitations play in the search for the fundamental? Need there be a fundamental level at all, or might there be an infinite descent of ever deeper levels? How can thinking in terms of fundamentality, or dependence, shed light on philosophical debates? No knowledge of physics is required.
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            *
           </em>
           Prerequistes: History of Philosophy, Theoretical Philosophy, or Practical Philosophy Elective (PHIL-AD 220-279).
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2 2013
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            7 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/kit-fine.html">
             Kit Fine
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             MW, 1:00-3:40pm
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2015
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/gabriel-rabin.html">
             Gabriel Rabin
            </a>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;

         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHIL-AD%20360">

         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           An advanced seminar that involves the careful study of some particular theory, philosopher, or set of issues in contemporary practical philosophy. Examples: consequentialism, empirical moral psychology, the philosophy of law, the ethics of gender, Rawls, metaethics.

           <em>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="true" data-id="PHIL-AD 400">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHIL-AD%20400">
          PHIL-AD 400 Senior Capstone Research Project
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           The capstone experience provides seniors with the opportunity to work closely with a faculty mentor and to conduct extensive research on a topic of their choice. The program consists of a capstone seminar, taken in the first semester of the senior year, and a year-long individualized thesis tutorial. During the capstone seminar, students define a thesis topic of their choice, develop a bibliography, read broadly in background works, and begin their research. In the tutorial, students work on a one-to-one basis with a faculty member to hone their research and produce successive drafts of a senior thesis. The capstone experience culminates in the public presentation of the senior thesis. Students may also elect to participate in a College Capstone Project with students majoring in other disciplines, such as the arts, and the natural and social sciences. Collaborating students work with a faculty member to define the overall goals of the Capstone Project, as well as the particular goals of each participant.
          </p>
          <p>
           *NOTE: As of Fall 2013 Capstone under HUM-AD 400
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="required">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="15">
            Philosophy
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PHYED-AD 1">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHYED-AD%201">
          PHYED-AD 1 Fitness for Life
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Learn how to use cardio and strength training equipment safely and effectively. Individualized exercise programs are designed to maximize progress based on cardiovascular and strength evaluations. Supervised progressive workouts teach individuals to achieve personal fitness goals through strength and aerobic interval circuit training on strength machines, treadmills, elliptical trainers, stair climbers, bicycles, and rowing ergometers.
          </p>

           *Note: Special Tuesday class on Saturday, November 29, 2014. No class on Tuesday, December 2, 2014.

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PHYED-AD 10">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHYED-AD%2010">
          PHYED-AD 10 Aerobics (women only)
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This comprehensive aerobics class will cover all aspects of movement with the focus on maintaining a targeted heart rate to maximize cardio benefit.  This women's only class will be taught by an in-house instructor.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 1 2011
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            7 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <span class="schedule">
             W, 4:15-5:45
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi

        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHYED-AD%2011">
          PHYED-AD 11 Fencing
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This introductory course will expose students to the basics of fencing and help identify those students who have potential to be competitive fencers.  Talented fencers will be directed to the Fencing Club with the long term goal of establishing a competitive intercollegiate fencing team.  This course will be taught by a contracted instructor.
          </p>
          <p>
           *Note (Fall 2/ 2014) : An additional practice / catch-up session is available on Thursdays.

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PHYED-AD 13">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHYED-AD%2013">
          PHYED-AD 13 Jiu Jitsu
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Jiu Jitsu is a strategic grappling sport where one manipulates an opponent’s force against himself rather than confronting it with one’s own force. Individuals learn how to apply the fundamental techniques of Jiu Jitsu, including positioning, leverage, joint locks, escapes, submissions, and self-defense.
          </p>
          <p>
           *Note (Fall 2/ 2014) : An additional practice / catch-up session is available on Thursdays.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PHYED-AD 14">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHYED-AD%2014">
          PHYED-AD 14 Pilates and Yoga (women only)
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Pilates is a conditioning program emphasizing the concepts of core strength and stabilization. Through highly focused and controlled movements, individuals experience increased body awareness, flexibility, coordination, and strength. In the yoga portion of this course, individuals learn the basic disciplines of yoga, focusing on body awareness, beginning yoga postures, breathing, and relaxation skills. Upon successful completion, students understand and are able to demonstrate the basic components of yoga practice, including safe, stable body alignment and classic yoga postures.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 1 2011
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            7 Weeks
           </span>

           <span class="meeting">
            <span class="schedule">
             MR, 4:15-5:45
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PHYED-AD 17">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHYED-AD%2017">
          PHYED-AD 17 Beginner Golf
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This driving range and putting green based golf instruction class is focused on exposing individuals to the basics of golf. In addition to receiving technical instruction on proper grip and swing, individuals learn the history and rules of golf and basic golf etiquette. The class culminates with an on-course experience.
          </p>
          <p>
           * Note: Transport departs Sama at 4:15 pm, arriving back by 6:15pm.

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PHYED-AD 18">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHYED-AD%2018">
          PHYED-AD 18 Karting and Driver Fitness
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Karting is a motor sport with small, open, four- wheeled vehicles racing on scaled-down circuits. In addition to developing quick reflexes, precision vehicle control, and decision-making skills, individuals gain a basic understanding of what can be altered to try to improve the competitiveness of the kart, including tire pressure, gearing, seat position, and chassis stiffness. The driver fitness portion of the class focuses on the physical fitness training necessary to effectively compete as a race car driver, including strength and cardiovascular training so as to handle steering, braking and the G-forces associated therewith.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2 2011
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            7 Weeks

          </p>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PHYED-AD 23">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHYED-AD%2023">
          PHYED-AD 23 Triathlon Training
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This challenging class is focused on developing athletes interested in competing in local triathlons, including the Yas Tri and Abu Dhabi International Triathlon. Individuals develop a personal triathlon training program—swim, bike and run. Workouts include indoor work on stationary bicycles, rowing ergometers, outdoor work on bicycles, distance swimming, running, and weight training. Individuals learn the secrets of competitive triathletes, including training techniques, equipment, race strategies and nutrition. NOTE: This is a physically demanding class with a challenging culmination.
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Prerequiste: must pass the NYUAD swim survival test, and must be able to ride a bike
           </em>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2 2011
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            7 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PHYED-AD 24">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHYED-AD%2024">
          PHYED-AD 24 Pilates and Nutrition
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Pilates is a conditioning program emphasizing the concepts of core strength and stabilization. Through highly focused and controlled movements, individuals experience increased body awareness, flexibility, coordination, and strength. Upon successful completion, students understand and are able to demonstrate the basic components of Pilates practice.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="104">
            Physical Education
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PHYED-AD 25">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHYED-AD%2025">
          PHYED-AD 25 Swimming (women's only)
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Individuals are evaluated for basic swimming abilities and comfort level in an aquatic environment. The front crawl, backstroke, breast stroke, and side stroke are taught. Skill instruction in beginning diving, floating/treading water, and underwater swimming, as well as safety awareness in and around the water are included.
          </p>
         </div>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PHYED-AD 27">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHYED-AD%2027">
          PHYED-AD 27 Aerobics
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           A low impact, rhythmic exercise, and aerobic move- ment class set to music. Body strength, flexibility, and cardiovascular fitness are developed through a combination of exercise routines. Overall total health is emphasized through discussions on nutri- tion, posture, stress management, and goal setting.
          </p>
         </div>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PHYED-AD 28">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHYED-AD%2028">
          PHYED-AD 28 Squash
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This class is geared towards novice and intermediate players and will expose individuals to the basics of squash.  In addition to receiving technical instruction in serve, forehand and backhand strokes, individuals will learn the rules of squash and participate in a weekly squash ladder.
          </p>
          <p>
           *Note (Fall 2014) : An additional practice / catch-up session is available on Sundays.

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PHYED-AD 32">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHYED-AD%2032">
          PHYED-AD 32 Bootcamp
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course offers intense exercise sessions that challenge every muscle of the body. By rapidly moving from exercise to exercise with little rest in between, one tones and firms muscles while simultaneously getting a vigorous cardiovascular workout.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 1 2012
           </span>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PHYED-AD 33">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHYED-AD%2033">
          PHYED-AD 33 Performance Boxing
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           The aim of this course is to gain a greater understanding of boxing technique and how to adapt authentic boxing training for pure fitness. Boxing for fitness is fun and at the same time builds muscle strength, improves body tone, promotes cardiovascular health, and enhances confidence.
          </p>
          <p>
           *Note: Special Tuesday class on Saturday, November 29, 2014. No class onTuesday, December 2, 2014.

        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHYED-AD%2036">

         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course aims to teach students the proper execution and techniques for strength training. Exercise routinesare focused onincreasing metabolism and energy levels, while developing healthier muscles, joints and bones.

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PHYED-AD 37">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHYED-AD%2037">
          PHYED-AD 37 Total Fitness
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Total Fitness describes its strength and conditioning program as “constantly varied, high intensity, functional movement”. It is a program geared to prepare the body for better fitness by not focusing on any one activity. Rather, Total Fitness wants the body prepared for any and all activities or sports. It focuses on core strengthening and conditioning. It is not the same routine every day, but a regular mixture of activities designed to activate and strengthen various core and major muscle groups from a variety of tasks. Workouts are typically short—20 minutes or less—and intense, demanding all-out physical exertion. They combine movements such as sprinting, rowing, jumping rope, climbing rope, flipping tires, weightlifting, and carrying sandbags, kettlebells etc. CrossFit has attracted elite athletes, military personnel, police officers and now regular people who want to achieve higher levels of fitness. The Total Fitness program seeks to achieve this through balance in ten fitness categories: heart and lung endurance, stamina, strength, flexibility, power, speed, coordination, agility, balance and accuracy.
          </p>
          <p>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 1 2013
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            7 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <span class="schedule">
             MW, 12:30-2:00 PM
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PHYED-AD 38">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHYED-AD%2038">
          PHYED-AD 38 Scuba (Womens Only)
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This is a PADI Certified Open Water Scuba Diving Course. Individuals who successfully complete this class are awarded an internationally recognized certificate in scuba diving. Prerequisites: (1) the ability to swim continuously for 200meter or 300meter with mask/fin snorkel, (2) the ability to swim/float in water too deep to stand in for 10minutes, (3) confidence in open water, and (4) the completion of a medical questionnaire with physician’s consent, PE credit will be awarded upon obtaining a PADI Open Water Dive qualification prior to the end of the class. Given the progressive nature of instruction; i.e. later classes are entirely dependent upon earlier classes, students must attend all sessions in the order offered.  If a session is missed, the affected student is solely responsible for scheduling and paying for the makeup session. All makeup sessions must be completed prior to the next regularly scheduled session.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 1 2013
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            7 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <span class="schedule">
             UW, 5:30-7:00 PM (Open Water: 8:00 AM -3:00 PM)
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>

        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHYED-AD%2040">
          PHYED-AD 40 Bowling
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This introductory course will expose students to the basics of bowling, including technique, tactics, handicaps and scorekeeping. By the end of the course, students have the capabilities be able to engage in a bowling league and/or competition. This course will be taught by a contracted instructor.
          </p>
          <p>
           Location – Zayed Sports City
          </p>
          <p>
           Transport Leaves Sama at 5:30pm
          </p>
          <p>
           Limited to 12 students
          </p>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PHYED-AD 41">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHYED-AD%2041">
          PHYED-AD 41 Body Sculpting
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Body Sculpting is a non-aerobic class focusing on muscle-toning and core strength. By engaging in traditional weight-training moves with moderate weights, students will be instructed in the most effective exercises and proper form for targeting all of the muscle groups in the body-e.g. Quads, Hamstrings, Gluteus, Calves, Chest, Back, Shoulders, Biceps, Triceps and Abdominals.  This course will be taught by an in-house instructor.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="104">
            Physical Education
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PHYED-AD 42">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHYED-AD%2042">
          PHYED-AD 42 Calisthenics
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Calisthenics involves bodyweight only workouts using rhythmic exercises (e.g. Jumping Jacks, Pushups, Crunches and Trunk Twists) thereby promoting strength, endurance, flexibility and general well-being. This course will be taught by an in-house instructor.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="104">
            Physical Education
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PHYED-AD 43">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PHYED-AD%2043">
          PHYED-AD 43 Corrective Excercise
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course is a combination of three corrective exercise methods, namely Trigger Point Therapy, Rehabilitation and Muscle Activation.
           <br/>
           Trigger Point Therapy will relieve the muscle tightness and increase range of motion, facilitating efficient blood circulation. This actually increases energy levels, muscle strength and delays fatigue which is invaluable to the competitive athlete. The range of motion will enable you to use the full potential of the muscle and the restored muscle with improved blood supply; will be able to work harder for much longer, without tightening up on you. Essentially what this amounts to is a dramatic Improvement in your sports performance.
           <br/>
           Rehabilitation of muscles can bring about reduced pain and accelerated healing of injured tissue, Improved range of motion and muscle mass, Strengthening, conditioning, and weight loss and better overall well-being and improved quality of life.
           <br/>
           Muscle activation looks at the body compensations as it loses its ability to engage the prime movers of the body. These compensations reduce the ability of the body to work at its highest effectiveness, and increase the risk of injury.
          </p>
          <p>
           This course will be taught by an in-house instructor.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 1 2013
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            7 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <span class="schedule">
             UT, 6:30pm-8:00pm
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
