       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="POLSC-AD 153">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=POLSC-AD%20153">
          POLSC-AD 153 Comparative Politics of South Asia
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           How did the borders of South Asian countries come to be formed? What explains the variation in the types of regimes—democratic and authoritarian— across South Asia? To what extent do these countries vary in the structure of their states as well as regimes? How does ethnic diversity affect the politics of South Asian countries? What is the pattern of economic growth across these countries, and their human development record and why? What explains the high levels of violence in some South Asian countries and patterns of variation across these countries? These are some of the questions that this course addresses, with a primary focus on India and a secondary focus on Pakistan, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, Nepal, Burma, and Bhutan. Although students learn a vast number of facts about the history and politics of the region, the primary purpose of the course is to identify overarching patterns that characterize the politics of these regions—and to teach students to think analytically and comparatively about these patterns.
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Recommended Prerequisites: Introduction to Comparative Politics (POLSC-AD 150).
           </em>
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Students in the NYUNY Politics Dept: This course is equivalent to POL-UA 562 Comparative Politics of South Asia.
           </em>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2 2012
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            7 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            Kanchan Chandra
								
								
								
									 -
            <span class="schedule">
             MW, 1:10-3:50
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2014
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            Rachel Brule
								
								
								
									 -
            <span class="schedule">
             MW, 9:15-10:30 am
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="POLSC-AD 155J">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=POLSC-AD%20155J">
          POLSC-AD 155J Politics in Modern Europe
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course explores the politics of the EU, of central and eastern Europe, and of western Europe. With regard to the EU, classical governance issues of popular representation and accountable elite decision-making are both sharply drawn and the subject of explicit agreements between states. These same issues were explicitly confronted in the recent past by those involved in democratization and democratic consolidation central and eastern Europe. Western Europe is the intellectual "home" to many of the classical models of popular representation and accountable elite decision-making, yet all countries, and especially smaller countries, are now forced to adapt these models in a setting where the traditional notion of the "stand alone" nation-state is becoming ever less relevant.
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            <br/>
            <em>
             <em>
             </em>
            </em>
           </em>
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Recommended Prerequisites: Introduction to Comparative Politics (POLSC-AD 150)
           </em>
          </p>
          <p>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            January 2013
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            Simon Hix, Michael Laver, Joshua Tucker

             T, BD
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             London, England
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="POLSC-AD 156">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=POLSC-AD%20156">
          POLSC-AD 156 Power and Politics in America
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course has as a central focus the political institutions of the United States and the effects of those institutions on policy outcomes. The course also places these institutions in the context of those of other wealthy democracies, as a means of illustrating several of the unique features of American political institutions. Topics covered in the course include separation of powers, federalism, and single-member district electoral rules.
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Recommended Prerequisites: Statistics for the Social and Behavioral Sciences (SOCSC-AD 110), Introduction to Political Thinking (POLSC-AD 130)
           </em>
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Students NYUNY: This course counts for Societies and Social Sciences (College Core) credit; For the NYUNY Philosophy Dept: This course is equivalent to
           </em>
           <em>
            POL-UA 300 Power &amp; Politics in America
           </em>
          </p>
          <p>
          </p>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="POLSC-AD 157JX">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=POLSC-AD%20157JX">
          POLSC-AD 157JX Bridging the Divide Between the Arab World and the West
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           The course provides students with an opportunity to engage in a multifaceted examination of Arab perceptions of the U.S. and the West, and Western perceptions of the Arab world. Students review literature and press examples of how Arab and Western media, popular culture, and political commentary portray each other. They design and execute a public opinion survey of U.S. and Arab attitudes in order to better understand how each side sees the other—using the poll-driven data to measure the gaps in understanding. The course also includes a televised town hall discussion with the students as participants engaging each other and peers from across the region in an examination of the topic.
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Students in the NYUNY MEIS Dept: This course counts for MEIS elective credit.
           </em>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="POLSC-AD 158">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=POLSC-AD%20158">
          POLSC-AD 158 Comparative Legislatures
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course introduces students to many aspects of legislative politics across the democratic world, addressing the questions of what legislatures do during a given legislative period and why they do this. The course provides students with a set of tools for understanding how legislatures are organized and how legislators behave. Topics examined include: congressional and parliamentary elections; the role of political parties and interest groups in lawmaking and elections; the impact of internal organization of legislatures on lawmaking; and "policy space" within which legislative decision making takes place.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="POLSC-AD 159X">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=POLSC-AD%20159X">
          POLSC-AD 159X Public Policy Challenges in the Middle East
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Public policy is a major facet of the political economy of states and societies. It comprises the instruments by which public authorities shape incentives to push and prod their societies and economies in desired directions. This course has two main objectives: to introduce students to major policy issues that face virtually all political systems and to understand them through the prism of Arab politics and society. Successful political systems are those that adjust best and most quickly to unexpected reactions to specific incentives. In the Arab Middle East political authorities in several regimes have relied on implicit social contracts to hold their populations politically inactive. Since the winter of 2011 social contract incentives have broken down, and no Arab regime has successfully coped with the break down. This course considers the subsequent public policy challenges.
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Students in the NYUNY Politics Dept: This course counts for a Politics elective.
           </em>
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Students in the NYUNY MEIS Dept: This course counts for MEIS elective credit.
           </em>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="POLSC-AD 160J">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=POLSC-AD%20160J">
          POLSC-AD 160J Social Media and Political Participation
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           In recent years, social media usage (Facebook, Twitter, Linked In, Tumbler, etc.) has exploded to such an extent that it is impossible to believe it does not have an effect on the political behavior of citizens. The question remains, though, of how exactly does it matter? This is the focus of our course. In the morning sessions, student are first introduced to the most important topics of political behavior—voting, turnout, partisanship, public opinion formation, and protests and social movements—and then to the much newer literature on the usage of social media. In the afternoon sessions, students both visit social media companies located in New York City, and are taught the necessary tools to work on their own original research projects. These research projects are conducted in conjunction with NYU’s new Social Media and Political Participation laboratory (smapp.nyu.edu).
          </p>
          <p>
           *For NYU New York and NYU Shanghai students interested in this course, please submit the
           <a href="http://nyuad.nyu.edu/en/academics/global-education/jterm-application-nyu.html">
            application
           </a>
           by October 15th. For more information about NYU Abu Dhabi courses being offered during January term visit our
           <a href="http://www.nyu.edu/admissions/january-term/nyu-abu-dhabi-january-term.html">
            website
           </a>
           .
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="POLSC-AD 161">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=POLSC-AD%20161">
          POLSC-AD 161 Comparative Politics of Africa
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           The goal of this course is to introduce participants to the study of African politics from multiple methodological approaches and in a number of African contexts. The course begins with the historical roots of contemporary African politics, exploring how pre-colonial institutions and colonialism shaped African politics at independence. Then, we survey the political and economic strategies of leaders post-independence and the factors shaping those strategies. We examine the causes and consequences of poor governance, and evaluate the recent patterns of redemocratization on the continent. The course closes with a discussion of present-day challenges: electoral malfeasance, public health crises, the “new” populism, and China in Africa.
          </p>
          <p>
           * Recommended prerequisite: POLSC-AD 150.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2014
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/jonathan-andrew-harris.html">
             Jonathan Andrew Harris
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             MW, 3:35-4:50 pm
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>

         </p>

       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="POLSC-AD 170">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=POLSC-AD%20170">
          POLSC-AD 170 Introduction to International Politics
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           The goal of this course is to introduce the basic analytical concepts and techniques that are essential for understanding international politics. We are especially concerned with analytically exploring major issues in international politics, such as the causes of war, the emergence of cooperative trade relations between states, the origins and functioning of international organizations such as the United Nations, and the political determinants of financial crises. The focus of the course is neither historical nor descriptive; rather, it requires students to exercise skills in logic and to think of imaginative ways to apply subtle techniques to gain a clearer grasp of the above political issues.
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Recommended Prerequisites: Statistics for the Social and Behavioral Sciences (SOCSC-AD 110), Introduction to Political Thinking (POLSC-AD 130)
           </em>
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            This course will be accepted as prerequisite for senior seminars in International Politics at NYUNY.
           </em>
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            <em>
            </em>
            Students in the NYUNY Politics Dept: This course is equivalent to
           </em>
           <em>
            POL-UA 700 International Politics
           </em>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 1 2012
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            7 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/peter-rosendorff.html">
             Peter Rosendorff
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             MR, 1:00-4:00
            </span>

             Abu Dhabi

           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks

           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">

             Defne Ezgi

            </span>

            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi

           </span>

          <li class="section">

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="POLSC-AD 171">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=POLSC-AD%20171">
          POLSC-AD 171 International Conflict
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course explores the conditions that lead to the initiation, escalation, spread, termination, and consequences of international conflict as well as the circumstances that promote, preserve, or restore peace. The main objective is to identify strategies that promote cooperative solutions to international disputes and to evaluate those strategies in terms of their historical effectiveness. The course emphasizes the application of models of strategic rational action as tools for assessing relations between nations, coupled with statistical and historical analysis of classes of events.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="124">
            Political Science
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="3">
            Multidisciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="166">
            Peace Studies
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="19">
            Political Science
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="62">
            International Politics
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="prerequisites">
          <li>
           Introduction to International Politics
          </li>
         </ul>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="POLSC-AD 172">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=POLSC-AD%20172">
          POLSC-AD 172 International Organization
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course covers the formal theory of international cooperation, including the reasons why countries choose to cooperate, bargaining over and enforcement of international agreements, and multilateralism. The remainder of the course discusses empirical examples including peacekeeping, collective security, economic and environmental cooperation, human rights treaties, and arms control.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>

           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="124">
            Political Science
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;

          </li>
          <li class="elective">

            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="19">

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="POLSC-AD 173">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=POLSC-AD%20173">
          POLSC-AD 173 International Political Economy
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course serves as an introduction to the workings of the contemporary international political-economic system and introduces students to some of the main analytical frameworks that political economists use to understand this system. The course seeks to familiarize students with analytical tools that help them gain a better understanding of the current problems and opportunities facing actors in today’s international political economy.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2014
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="POLSC-AD 174">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=POLSC-AD%20174">
          POLSC-AD 174 Domestic Determinants of International Relations
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Prerequisites: Introduction to International Politics.  Domestic political circumstances affect the policy incentives of leaders. Hence domestic political institutions, economic performance, and popularity all influence foreign policy. In turn, international outcomes influence the domestic survival of leaders. This course explores the theoretical linkages between domestic and international events.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="124">
            Political Science
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="19">
            Political Science
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="62">
            International Politics
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="POLSC-AD 176J">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=POLSC-AD%20176J">
          POLSC-AD 176J Nation-Building
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Nation-Building explores the range of strategies which strong states use in order to build the capacity of weak ones. This is a matter, not of morality, but of national security. Thanks to globalization, the poisons which brew inside weak or failing states can now infect neighbors, or countries halfway across the globe; the terrorist attacks of 9/11 reinforced this lesson with terrible force. But is it really possible for outsiders to help build solid economic and political structures in fragile states? Is "democracy promotion" a contradiction in terms? Experience in places like Afghanistan or Haiti is hardly encouraging. The class asks what can be done, and by whom, and in what kind of setting. We visit UN officials in New York and government officials in Washington, as well as experts in both places.
          </p>
          <p>
           *For NYU New York and NYU Shanghai students interested in this course, please submit the
           <a href="http://nyuad.nyu.edu/en/academics/global-education/jterm-application-nyu.html">
            application
           </a>
           by October 15th. For more information about NYU Abu Dhabi courses being offered during January term visit our
           <a href="http://www.nyu.edu/admissions/january-term/nyu-abu-dhabi-january-term.html">
            website
           </a>
           .
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            January 2013
           </span>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="POLSC-AD 177">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=POLSC-AD%20177">
          POLSC-AD 177 Civil Wars and International Intervention
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Civil war continues to be one of the most vexing problems in comparative and international politics. Why do civil wars break out? Aside from the obvious physical destruction caused by civil conflict what are the effects of civil conflict on society? How can the international community help end civil conflicts? We address these questions in this course. The course is broken into two parts starting with the causes of civil conflict, then moving on to what, if anything, the international community can do to ameliorate this problem.
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Prerequisites: Introduction to International Politics (POLSC-AD 170) and Introduction to Econometrics (ECON-AD 210) or Data Analysis (POLSC-AD 209)
           </em>
          </p>
          <p>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2013
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks

            </span>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="POLSC-AD 178J">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=POLSC-AD%20178J">
          POLSC-AD 178J Understanding Insurgency and Counterinsurgency
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Insurgencies continue to be a major threat to peace in developing countries. How do insurgencies arise? Why do people join insurgent movements? What strategies do insurgent movements pursue? What can states do to address insurgent movements most effectively? This course addresses these questions. It begins with a review of the scholarly literature on insurgency. Students then travel to Kathmandu, Nepal to meet with participants in Nepal's 10-year civil war from 1996 to 2006 and learn their perspectives on these questions obtained from their experiences.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            January 2014
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/michael-gilligan.html">
             Michael Gilligan
            </a>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            January 2015
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/michael-gilligan.html">

            </a>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="POLSC-AD 179J">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=POLSC-AD%20179J">
          POLSC-AD 179J Political Conflict and Economic Development
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           It is now widely acknowledged that political conflicts play a major role in driving economic development trajectories.  We will study how political conflicts impact economic development, using examples from Latin America’s rich political and economic history to better understand the conflict-development relationship.  The course will follow a seminar format and students will be encouraged to compare the conflict-development relationship in Latin America with that of their own country, and come up with explanations for differences between the two.  The course will include multiple field trips to significant sites for Argentina’s political conflicts.
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            *Note: Students in the NYUNY Politics Dept:
            <em>
             This course counts for Politics in the
            </em>
            <em>
             Comparative Politics Politics field
            </em>
           </em>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            January 2014
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            Shanker Satyanath
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Buenos Aires, Argentina

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="POLSC-AD 180">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=POLSC-AD%20180">
          POLSC-AD 180 Political Economy of International Trade
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course covers five major topics in international political economy: international trade and trade policy (tariffs, quotas, trade agreements); international migration and remittances; offshoring and outsourcing; international finance (exchange rates, cross-border investment, central bank policy); crises of the international economy: the 1930s, 2007–2009, and the current crises of the Euro and of European sovereign debt.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2013
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/ronald-rogowski.html">
             Ronald Rogowski
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             MW, 2:35PM-3:50PM
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="POLSC-AD 181">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=POLSC-AD%20181">
          POLSC-AD 181 Ethnicity and Violence
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           A seminar devoted to investigating (1) where ethnic division comes from (2) how ethnicity relates to politics, and (3) why politics often turn violent. This course covers seminal papers and readings that have helped academics and policymakers understand the root causes of ethnic conflict and other specific forms of violence including civil war, insurgency, revolution, and terrorism.
          </p>
          <p>
           *Recommended: One or more of the following courses; ECON-AD 101, ECON-AD 105, ECON-AD 210, POLSC-AD 209, SOCSC-AD 113, SRPP-AD 120.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2014
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/christopher-paik.html">
             Christopher Paik
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             TR, 9:55-11:10 AM
            </span>
            <br/>

            <em class="location">

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="POLSC-AD 182J">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=POLSC-AD%20182J">
          POLSC-AD 182J Energy, Development, and International Politics
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           In many respects, the social and political organization of societies has depended on access to and control of energy—whether provided by animals, human labor, or natural resources. The industrial revolution initially occurred in locations where coal was available. The discovery of oil, which provided a more transportable and more powerful source of energy, launched international competition for control of sources of oil. Oil cartels and powerful transnational oil companies have played vital roles in the politics, economics, and international policies of developed and developing nations, and access to oil has shaped the relationship of the Middle East to the world from the early 20th century to the present. This course explores these historical developments and considers how the need for energy has defined domestic politics and world developments over the past two centuries. Taking advantage of our location in Abu Dhabi, the course explores the relationship of an oil-producing region to the rest of the world.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            January 2014
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/alan-kimball.html">
             Alan Kimball
            </a>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="124">
            Political Science
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="POLSC-AD 183J">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=POLSC-AD%20183J">
          POLSC-AD 183J Emerging Powers
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Are Emerging Powers emerging, and are they powers? The course will consider the emerging "market" or economic discussion, reviewing what academics, the press, financial institutions, etc., mean when they speak of these countries, with acronyms such as BRICs, BRICS, MINT, and others.  What is the key factor: size, growth, novelty,  potential or promise? Which of all of these questions is truly relevant and important?  The second part of the class will examine regional, geopolitical issues: are these countries important actors in their regions? Why or why not, and how does their economic performance influence their regional political action (domestic ideological and institutional issues would also be rapidly addressed here)? The third part of the class will turn to international and multilateral factors: are "emerging powers" truly powers? Are they all the same? Do others see them as powers? How do they express their economic success or geographic and demographic clout in the international arena?
          </p>
          <p>
           *For NYU New York and NYU Shanghai students interested in this course, please submit the application by October 15th. For more information about NYU Abu Dhabi courses being offered during January term visit our website.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            January 2015
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            Jorge Castañeda
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="19">
            Political Science
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="62">
            International Politics
           </span>
          </li>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="POLSC-AD 209">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=POLSC-AD%20209">
          POLSC-AD 209 Data Analysis
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Social scientists and policy analysts rely heavily on research drawing on observational data. Students learn to manage and analyze such data and to deploy statistical techniques that are common in these applications, with an emphasis on how to translate social science theory into empirical research. Topics include review of basic regression analysis, building multivariate analytical models, and regression analysis with limited dependent variables. The course emphasizes practical training in these skills as well as evaluation, replication, and critical analysis of research conducted in the social science literature. The course assumes knowledge of the material covered in Statistics for Social and Behavioral Sciences and is designed as alternative for students in the social sciences who are not taking
           <em>
            Introduction to Econometrics.
           </em>
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Students in the NYUNY Politics Dept: This course counts for a Politics elective.
           </em>
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Prerequisites: MATH-AD 150 or SOCSC-AD 110 or SOCS-AD 113.
           </em>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PSYCH-AD 100">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PSYCH-AD%20100">
          PSYCH-AD 100 Introduction to Linguistics
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course offers an introduction to linguistics, the scientific study of language. The focus of linguistics within the cognitive sciences is to understand how it is that humans are able to speak and understand natural language, how they acquire this ability, and how they put it to use. The ability to speak and understand language is unique to humans and universally represented within the species. It affords us, together with other faculties of the mind, the ability to achieve levels of abstract thinking as well as social organization, which is unprecedented in the animal kingdom. Language is therefore one of the most characteristic features that we have as a species, and its study is of central importance to understanding what it is to be human.
          </p>
          <p>
           This course is available for all students but will not count towards the Psychology major.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2014
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/stephanie-harves.html">
             Stephanie Harves
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             TR, 1:10-2:25 PM
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="20">
            Psychology
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="162">
            Courses for Non-Majors
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PSYCH-AD 101">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PSYCH-AD%20101">
          PSYCH-AD 101 Introduction to Psychology
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Introduction to the fundamental principles of psychology, emphasizing both the unity and diversity of a field that spans major theoretical and research areas, including biological bases of human behavior, learning, development, motivation, as well as social and abnormal behavior. Opportunities to apply knowledge gained in lectures and readings are available through computer-based demonstrations, in-class exercises, and required field experiences.
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Students NYUNY: This course counts for Societies and Social Sciences (College Core) credit; For the NYUNY Psychology Dept: This course counts is equivalent to PSYCH-UA 1 Introduction to Psychology
           </em>
           <em>
           </em>
          </p>
          <p>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2011
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/pj-henry.html">
             PJ Henry
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             MR, 1:10-2:25
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2012
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/pj-henry.html">
             PJ Henry
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             MW, 4:00-5:15
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="section">

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PSYCH-AD 102">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PSYCH-AD%20102">
          PSYCH-AD 102 Research Methods in Psychology
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course offers an overview of diverse research designs involving quantitative and qualitative methods. It is an introduction to essential elements of psychological research, including the formulation of questions and hypotheses, identification of variables and operational definitions, participant sampling, data collection, and basic analytical techniques. Students get to know the main elements and logic of psychological research and develop a conceptual and critical understanding of rigorous analysis.
          </p>
         </div>
         <p class="lab">
          This course has a
          <strong>
           laboratory component
          </strong>
          .
         </p>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PSYCH-AD 105">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PSYCH-AD%20105">
          PSYCH-AD 105 Introduction to Biopsychology
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Biopsychology is concerned with the biological basis of psychological processes and behaviors. In this course, students discover connections between psychology and biology, pharmacology, endocrinology, as well as genetics. In particular, students get to know the structure, function and development of the human nervous and hormone system and discuss how such systems can give rise to basic sensory, motor, cognitive, and motivational processes that characterize the human mind. Additionally, through learning about the effects of brain damage, students gain insights on how pathological thoughts and behaviors can be rooted in physiological causes. Finally, students develop a basic understanding of the methodologies used in biopsychology and evaluate the contributions as well as limitations of these approaches.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2015
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/kartik-katepalli-sreenivsan.html">
             Kartik Katepalli Sreenivsan
            </a>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="required">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="20">
            Psychology
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>

         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PSYCH-AD 110">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PSYCH-AD%20110">
          PSYCH-AD 110 Cognition
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Cognitive psychology is the scientific study of the human mind and human thinking. This course is aimed at providing the student with a better understanding on how we humans perceive and think about ourselves and about the world. This is relevant beyond academic interest in the mind because our perception and thought processes are fraught with biases that nonetheless routinely inform human actions. Knowing about these biases and understanding their effects is crucial in a world in which human societies are becoming increasingly more interconnected. The course covers different aspects of perception, attention, memory, language, concepts, reasoning, problem solving, expertise, creativity, and decision-making. The course emphasizes how psychologists use experiments to learn about the structure of the human mind, including how the mind works and how human thinking, with all its successes and pitfalls, occurs.
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Students in the NYUNY Psychology Dept: This course is equivalent to PSYCH-UA 29
           </em>
           <em>
            Cognition.
           </em>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2012
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PSYCH-AD 111">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PSYCH-AD%20111">
          PSYCH-AD 111 Developmental Psychology
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course provides an introduction to the major theoretical issues and research in developmental psychology. It focuses on developmental processes and milestones from infancy through adolescence. Lectures interweave theory, methods, and findings about how we develop as perceiving, thinking, and feeling beings.
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Students in the NYUNY Psychology Dept: This course is equivalent to PSYCH-UA 34
           </em>
           <em>
            Developmental Psychology.
           </em>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PSYCH-AD 112">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PSYCH-AD%20112">
          PSYCH-AD 112 Perception
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           How do we construct a conception of physical reality based on sensory experience? This course provides a survey of basic facts, theories, and methods for studying sensation and perception. The major emphasis is on vision and audition, but other modalities may be covered. Representative topics include: receptor function and physiology; color; motion; depth; psycho physics of detection, discrimination, and appearance; perceptual constancies; adaptation, pattern recognition, and the interaction of knowledge and perception.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2015
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>

           <span data-category="154">
            Psychology

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PSYCH-AD 150">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PSYCH-AD%20150">
          PSYCH-AD 150 Social Psychology
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Introduction to theory and research about the social behavior of individuals, including perceptions of others and the self, attraction, affiliation, altruism and helping, aggression, moral thought and action, attitudes, influence, conformity, social exchange and bargaining, group decision making, leadership and power, and intergroup relations.
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Students in the NYUNY Psychology Dept: This course counts is equivalent to PSYCH-U.32 Social Psychology
           </em>
          </p>
          <p>

           </em>
          </p>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PSYCH-AD 151">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PSYCH-AD%20151">
          PSYCH-AD 151 Personality
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Introduction to the major theories of personality and research in personality, including such topics as the self-concept; unconscious processes; how we relate to others; and stress, anxiety, and depression. The work of various theorists is discussed as it relates to personality development throughout the life span.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">

           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="154">
            Psychology
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="20">
            Psychology
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="prerequisites">
          <li>
           Introduction to Psychology
          </li>
         </ul>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PSYCH-AD 152">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PSYCH-AD%20152">
          PSYCH-AD 152 Culture and Context
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           The aim of this class is to explore and analyze classic theories of culture and context in the field of psychology, with a specific emphasis on understanding how these processes shape human development. We will also examine research that focuses on cultural and contextual variability and similarity among youth and families from different parts of the world and how different forms of oppression and prejudice shape the developmental trajectories of youth.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2 2012
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            7 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/niobe-way.html">
             Niobe Way
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             UW, 9:55-12:35
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="154">
            Psychology
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="20">
            Psychology
           </span>
          </li>

           Introduction to Psychology
          </li>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PSYCH-AD 153J">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PSYCH-AD%20153J">
          PSYCH-AD 153J Culture, Context, and Psychology
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           The aim of this class is to explore and analyze classic theories of culture and context in the field of psychology, with a specific emphasis on understanding how these processes shape human development. We also examine research that focuses on cultural and contextual variability and similarity among youth and families from different parts of the world and how different forms of oppression and prejudice shape the developmental trajectories of youth.
          </p>
          <p>
           *For NYU New York and NYU Shanghai students interested in this course, please submit the
           <a href="http://nyuad.nyu.edu/en/academics/global-education/jterm-application-nyu.html">
            application
           </a>
           by October 15th. For more information about NYU Abu Dhabi courses being offered during January term visit our
           <a href="http://www.nyu.edu/admissions/january-term/nyu-abu-dhabi-january-term.html">
            website
           </a>
           .
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            January 2014
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/niobe-way.html">
             Niobe Way
            </a>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="section">

           These courses are high-level seminars offered on a wide variety of topics, including the history of psychology, emotion, motivation, social influence, intergroup relations, clinical and counseling psychology, and other focal themes. The topics will change to reflect the areas of research of the faculty at NYUAD and the affiliated faculty from NYUNY.

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PSYCH-AD 298-299">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PSYCH-AD%20298-299">
          PSYCH-AD 298-299 Directed Study in Psychology
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course is intended for students who are highly motivated and seek the opportunity to work in field or laboratory research with a faculty sponsor from the NYUAD Program in Psychology. Students with the necessary background in course work and who, in the opinion of a faculty sponsor, possess intellectual independence and ability may register for this course. The student must approach a faculty member in his or her field of interest to obtain sponsorship. Typically, this course is only open to students with a minimum overall GPA of 3.3 and a minimum major GPA of 3.5, and registration requires permission of the sponsoring faculty member. Forms for Directed Study in Psychology are available from the Office of the Dean of Science.
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Prerequisites include permisson of the instructor and PSYCH-AD 101 and 102, 105, and SOCSC-AD 110 or SOCSC-AD 113 or MATH-AD 150.
           </em>
          </p>
          <p>
          </p>
          <p>
          </p>
         </div>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PSYCH-AD 310">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PSYCH-AD%20310">
          PSYCH-AD 310 Abnormal Psychology
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           The kinds, dynamics, causes, and treatment of psychopathology. Topics include early concepts of abnormal behavior; affective disorders, anxiety disorders, psychosis, and personality disorders; the nature and effectiveness of traditional and modern methods of psychotherapy; and viewpoints of major psychologists past and present.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="20">
            Psychology
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="161">
            Advanced Electives
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="prerequisites">
          <li>
           Introduction to Psychology
          </li>
          <li>
           Research Methods in Psychology
          </li>
         </ul>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PSYCH-AD 311">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PSYCH-AD%20311">
          PSYCH-AD 311 Cognitive Neuroscience
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           The frontal cortex is thought to be a key cortical area important for the integration of sensory and motor information. Many cognitive and emotional facets of our behavior that make us unique as humans are thought to depend on the frontal cortex, which accounts for almost 1/3 of the cortical surface of the entire brain. In this course we cover important neuropsychological patient studies and theories as well as human and animal empirical studies into the structure and physiology of the frontal lobes as they relate to higher cognitive functions.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="154">
            Psychology
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="20">
            Psychology
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="161">
            Advanced Electives
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="prerequisites">
          <li>
           Introduction to Psychology
          </li>
          <li>
           Research Methods in Psychology
          </li>
         </ul>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PSYCH-AD 312">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PSYCH-AD%20312">
          PSYCH-AD 312 Decisionmaking
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course focuses in depth on a single aspect of thinking: decision-making. Decision-making is a critical part of every person’s life, as we make decisions about major life events such as what college to go to (if any), whether to get married, or what career to follow, down to trivial decisions about which bagel to order or where to sit in a class. We examine formal theories of how people/should/make decisions, as well as many studies on whether people are good or even rational decision maker.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="154">
            Psychology
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="20">
            Psychology
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="161">
            Advanced Electives
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="prerequisites">
          <li>
           Introduction to Psychology
          </li>
          <li>
           Research Methods in Psychology
          </li>
         </ul>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PSYCH-AD 313">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PSYCH-AD%20313">
          PSYCH-AD 313 Economic Psychology
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course introduces important concepts from psychology and behavioral economics, offering new ways of thinking about subjects as varied as personality, the dynamics of social groups, and the ways in which emotion affects decision making. The course is divided into two parts, the first concentrating on the psychology of individual decision making and the second emphasizing the social psychology of group behavior. In each case, the focus is on how behavioral research might potentially enrich “classical” economic theories, such as the choice-based theory of revealed preference. The course then applies these concepts to various topics within the social sciences, including the study of systematic biases in group decision-making, the role of the media and political advertising, race relations, the legitimacy of government institutions, and the formation of opinions and ideologies.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="20">
            Psychology
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="161">
            Advanced Electives
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="prerequisites">
          <li>
           Introduction to Psychology
          </li>
          <li>
           Research Methods in Psychology
          </li>
         </ul>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PSYCH-AD 314">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PSYCH-AD%20314">
          PSYCH-AD 314 Industrial and Organizational Psychology
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Personal, social, and environmental factors related to people’s attitudes and performance in industry and other organizations. Topics include personnel selection and evaluation, training and development, attitudes and motivation, leadership, group dynamics, organizational structure and climate, and job design and working conditions.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PSYCH-AD 315">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PSYCH-AD%20315">
          PSYCH-AD 315 Language and Mind
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course introduces students to the field of cognitive science through an examination of language behavior, one of the major domains of inquiry in the discipline. Begins with interactive discussions of how best to characterize and study the mind. These principles are then illustrated through an examination of research and theories related to language representation and use. The course draws from research in both formal linguistics and psycholinguistics.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="154">
            Psychology
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="20">
            Psychology
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="161">
            Advanced Electives
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="prerequisites">
          <li>
           Introduction to Psychology
          </li>
          <li>
           Research Methods in Psychology
          </li>
         </ul>

       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PSYCH-AD 316">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PSYCH-AD%20316">
          PSYCH-AD 316 Motivation and Volition
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           The course provides an overview of the major theories and findings in research on motivation and volition. We address the history of research on motivation and volition, classic phenomena of being motivated versus lacking motivation and willpower, the psychology of goals (goal setting, goal implementation, effortful goal pursuits, disengagement, content and structure of goals, the mental representation of goals), disorders of self-regulation, and cognitive-neuropsychological research as well as the perspective of economics on motivation and volition.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2013
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/antje-von-suchodoletz.html">
             Antje Von Suchodoletz
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             TR, 1:00-2:15
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2015
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">

            </a>
            <br/>

             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PSYCH-AD 317">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PSYCH-AD%20317">
          PSYCH-AD 317 Prejudice and Stereotyping
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course covers historical and contemporary scientific approaches to understanding prejudice, specifically prejudice that exists between social groups (for example, ethnic prejudice, religious prejudice, etc.) across different cultures. Readings cover topics including the origins of prejudice, the justification of prejudice, the different forms of prejudicial expression, the identification of prejudice in individuals and institutions, the consequences of being a victim of prejudice, and the value (or not) of different prejudice reduction strategies.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="20">
            Psychology
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="161">
            Advanced Electives
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="prerequisites">
          <li>
           Introduction to Psychology
          </li>
          <li>
           Research Methods in Psychology
          </li>
         </ul>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PSYCH-AD 318">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PSYCH-AD%20318">
          PSYCH-AD 318 The Psychology of Language
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Examines theories and research concerning the cognitive processes and linguistic representations that enable language comprehension and production. Topics include speech perception, visual processes during reading, word recognition, syntactic processing, and semantic/discourse processing.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="154">
            Psychology
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="20">
            Psychology
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="161">
            Advanced Electives
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="prerequisites">
          <li>
           Introduction to Psychology
          </li>
          <li>
           Research Methods in Psychology
          </li>
         </ul>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="PSYCH-AD 320">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=PSYCH-AD%20320">
          PSYCH-AD 320 Lab in Cognitive Neuroscience: MEG
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           A hands-on introduction to magnetoencephalography (MEG) as a cognitive neuroscience technique, with a focus on the neural basis of language. MEG measures the magnetic fields generated by neural activity and offers the best combination of temporal and spatial accuracy of extant non-invasive cognitive neuroscience techniques. As part of the Neuroscience of Language Lab (NeLLab), NYUAD houses a state-of-the-art MEG facility, which will be the primary site for this course. Students execute an MEG project including experimental design, data collection, analysis and write-up of results.
          </p>
          <p>
           Prerequisite is MATH-AD 150, or SOCSC-AD 110 or SOCSC-AD 113
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2 2013
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            7 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/mariliina-pylkkanen.html">
             Mariliina Pylkkanen
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             MW, 1:10-3:50 PM
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>

           This course appears in...
          </strong>

            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;

            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="154">
            Psychology
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="20">
            Psychology
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="161">
            Advanced Electives
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
