       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="VISAR-AD 155">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=VISAR-AD%20155">
          VISAR-AD 155 Exhibition Industry
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           The success of Frank Gehry’s Bilbao Guggenheim may be seen as the culmination of a paradigm shift away from the old idea of the museum as an art vault to a new conception of the museum as a programming center, a venue for high-profile temporary exhibitions, and a tourist attraction. This course explores the consequences for art and scholarship of the recent museum boom and asks what might it take to produce a change of direction.
          </p>
          <p>
           <em>
            Students in the NYUNY Art History Dept: This course counts for Art History elective credit.
           </em>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2012
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            Alexander Nagel
								
								
								
									 -
            <span class="schedule">
             U, 2:35-5:15
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">

           </span>

          <li class="elective">

            Visual Arts: History, Theory, Criticism
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">

           <span data-category="169">

         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=VISAR-AD%20156">
          VISAR-AD 156 Topics in East Asian Art
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           These courses focus on topics that are central to the study of the art and culture of China, Korea, and/or Japan. These courses investigate the social and historical contexts of artistic practice, as well as the construction of national or geographical conceptions of artistic traditions. These courses may also offer comparative perspectives that forge links to other areas of the curriculum.

         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course focuses on topics that are central to the study of the art and culture primarily of India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, and/or Sri Lanka. Traditions from other parts of the region (Afghanistan, Bhutan, Maldives, and Nepal) may also be considered. The course investigates the social and historical contexts of artistic practice, as well as the construction of national or geographical conceptions of artistic traditions. The course may also offer comparative perspectives that forge links to other areas of the curriculum.

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="VISAR-AD 159">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=VISAR-AD%20159">
          VISAR-AD 159 Architecture in Abu Dhabi and Dubai
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course investigates architecture, urban design and planning, with particular attention to buildings that are designed to serve as visual monuments to the city. Students explore urban design in Abu Dhabi and Dubai in relation to several contexts, including the history of garden sculpture and landscaping, the continuing traditions of Islamic arts in the region, and the development of contemporary Western architectural forms.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>

           &gt;

            Visual Arts
           </span>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="VISAR-AD 160">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=VISAR-AD%20160">
          VISAR-AD 160 Epic Architecture
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course investigates the social, political, and imaginative roles played by grand architecture from ancient times to the present day. Through such case studies as the Temple of Luxor, Stonehenge, the Taj Mahal, the Hagia Sophia, the Eiffel Tower, the Empire State Building, and the Sheikh Zayed Mosque, students investigate the historical contexts of monumental buildings and other structures that have been erected to serve as emblems of a national culture, as well as the ways that these monuments take on new life in literature and other forms of culture.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">

           </span>
           &gt;

           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="169">
            Art and Art History
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="171">
            Electives: Art History

         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course focuses on topics that are central to the study of architecture and its relation to the urban environment. Students investigate architecture in its urban setting from the different perspectives of architectural history, engineering, and urban planning, taking into account technological and environmental factors, as well as construction and transportation systems.

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="VISAR-AD 163J">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=VISAR-AD%20163J">
          VISAR-AD 163J Designing Abu Dhabi
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course guides students through the many facets of graphic design and visual communication, with a focus on the cross-cultural visual environment of Abu Dhabi and the Emirates. Students explore multiple aspects of visual design from aesthetics to user interfaces and usability, with special consideration of signage in Abu Dhabi. They also develop graphic designs that respond to the Abu Dhabi environment. Practical exercises that emphasize visual communication skills are central to the class. Students become familiar with the design procedures at the core of successful visual identity systems, thus developing their skills in research methodologies, data gathering, analysis, decision making, brainstorming and creative solutions, team work and monitoring.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            January 2013
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/goffredo-puccetti.html">
             Goffredo Puccetti
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             T, BD
            </span>
            <br/>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="VISAR-AD 164J">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=VISAR-AD%20164J">
          VISAR-AD 164J Photographic Practice
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           The class challenges students to look at and photograph the local environment/society, and to reflect on their images as a way of understanding how the broader world of photography operates in constructing our image of the world. Any theme/subject and photographic style may be chosen as long as some access to that subject can be gained. Students explore how to approach their
           <br/>
           subject, develop a theme, and how to choose images that reflect their experiences. They keep a journal, and a final presentation will include a group of photographs and a short personal essay.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            January 2013
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            Yasser Alwan
								
								
								
									 -
            <span class="schedule">
             T, BD
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>

          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations

          <li class="elective">

       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="VISAR-AD 165J">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=VISAR-AD%20165J">
          VISAR-AD 165J Gardens of Eden in the History of Art
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           The garden is one of the oldest modes of human intervention in the environment. This course explores the garden as a major art form by focusing on pictorial and spatial representations of the Garden of Eden. The Edenic Paradise of Genesis and the Qu’ran where Adam and Eve transgressed against God gives access to thought about gardens in the ancient Middle East. As a foundational figure in Judaic, Christian, and Islamic theology, the Garden of Eden spawned a history of interpretation that helped differentiate these religions. The history of Eden in the art of the peoples of the book is closely entwined with that of garden design, and the seminar examines both. We will study gardens in ancient Mesopotamia, early Christian monasteries, Syrian and Andalusian courtyards, Renaissance altarpieces, Enlightenment cities, Persian court miniatures, Mughal tomb complexes, and early American towns. To analyze these works, the course introduces fundamental methods of art history as an academic discipline.  The seminar includes field trips to gardens and collections in the UAE and India, and concludes with a collaborative garden design project in Abu Dhabi.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            January 2013
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/mariet-westermann.html">
             Mariet Westermann
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             T, BD
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            January 2014
           </span>
           <br/>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="VISAR-AD 166">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=VISAR-AD%20166">
          VISAR-AD 166 Foundations of Art History I
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           These courses offer detailed engagements with key works of art -- masterpieces to material culture across a range of media from different times and places -- to develop the critical apparatus of visual analysis. They introduce the methods and fundamental concepts of art history by taking one work of art and constructing around it a web of diverse objects and practices that allow us to grapple with the meanings of art and its histories within global and trans-historical perspectives. Among the questions we ask throughout the course are: What is art? What is art history? What are the institutions that shape the practice and dissemination of art? How is art affected by histories of cultural exchange? What is the nature of tradition? Visits to local museums. Lecture/discussion. Evaluation will be through written assignments, powerpoint presentations, and active class participation. No previous knowledge of art history required. This course fulfills Art and Art History requirements.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2013
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/reindert-falkenburg.html">
             Reindert Falkenburg
            </a>
            ,
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/shamoon-zamir.html">
             Shamoon Zamir
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             MW, 1:10-2:25 PM
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2014
           </span>

           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/reindert-falkenburg.html">
             Reindert Falkenburg
            </a>
            ,
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/shamoon-zamir.html">
             Shamoon Zamir
            </a>
            -
            <span class="schedule">
             TR, 10:40-11:55 am
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="VISAR-AD 167">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=VISAR-AD%20167">
          VISAR-AD 167 Global Renaissance
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           What did early modern globalization and material exchange across cultures and contact zones look like ? This interdisciplinary seminar will study the material culture produced by Europe’s first sustained overseas contact with the rest of the world by following the Portuguese, Spanish, Dutch and British maritime trade routes from the sixteenth through eighteenth centuries. Topics will include formal languages of artistic world-making; interwoven histories of exploration, collecting, and surveillance; technologies of personal or communal identities; and visual aspects of political diplomacy and subversion. Active class participation, brief powerpoint presentations and a research project. An art history course is preferred, but not required.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="174">
            Art and Art History: Art History
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="required">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="169">
            Art and Art History
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="169">
            Art and Art History
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="171">
            Electives: Art History
           </span>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="VISAR-AD 168">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=VISAR-AD%20168">
          VISAR-AD 168 American Art After 1945
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course will examine the remarkable development of American painting after World War II in dialogue with equally impressive achievements in the other arts in the United States. The primary focus will be on Abstract Expressionism or the New York School.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>

          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="VISAR-AD 169">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=VISAR-AD%20169">
          VISAR-AD 169 Photography, USA
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           The history of photography in the United States, from the middle of the nineteenth century to the present, is rich and varied. This course examines key figures, genres, episodes and works from this history.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>

           This course appears in...

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="VISAR-AD 170">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=VISAR-AD%20170">
          VISAR-AD 170 Contemporary Photography from the Middle East, South Asia, and the Far East
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course will introduce students to a wide range of contemporary photographic practices in the Middle East, South Asia, and the Far East. Through slide lectures, readings, museum visits and presentations by local artists, students will explore the issues that artists, photography collectives and competitions of the region have concerned themselves with. The course will cover a range of genres, including Landscape, Performance, Portraiture, Documentary.
          </p>
         </div>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="VISAR-AD 171X">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=VISAR-AD%20171X">
          VISAR-AD 171X Modern Art of the Arab World
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           In the short period of thirty years art of the Arab world moved from the periphery of the international art world to the center of global visual art production. The course examines the systems that have prompted this change and the theoretical framework that currently situates Arab art within the global discourse on visual art. Focusing on selected artists, the course explores the impact of political, social and market forces on the region’s art and the recent discourse on Islamic art and its links to modern and contemporary art of the region.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2013
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/salwa-mikdadi.html">

       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="VISAR-AD 172">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=VISAR-AD%20172">
          VISAR-AD 172 Iconoclasm and the Image
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Why has the interpretation of art weighted production over destruction? After all, reformers of all eras have sought to decapitate, maim and otherwise “erase” objects. Taking a long view of iconoclasm as the active interrogation of objects by objects—through case studies from ancient, medieval and reformation art to today’s contemporary crises—this course will consider the power of art from the frankly object-centered perspective of “applied criticism,” censorship and renunciation. Topics will include lineage and cyclical regeneration, protection and preservation, memory and ruin, economies of sight, mimesis and the miraculous object, senses and the infinite hermeneutic, rupture and the failure of the eye, and the hundred-eyed hydra of immediate, interconnected media images that freeze us today. Active class participation, brief powerpoint presentations and a research project. An art history course is preferred, but not required.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="174">
            Art and Art History: Art History
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="169">
            Art and Art History
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="171">
            Electives: Art History
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="VISAR-AD 173">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=VISAR-AD%20173">
          VISAR-AD 173 The Sensory Baroque
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           What is “baroque” ? This course attempts to understand the trials and tribulations of an intellectual ideal via recent work in sensory studies, the art of excess understood in terms of the body’s corporeal and spiritual senses. The masterpieces of seventeenth-century Baroque art—the work of Bernini, Rembrandt, Rubens, Velázquez and Vermeer—will be considered from the perspective of style, iconology, allegory, philosophy, and social theory. Topics will include unity and overflow, the sensual economy and its limits, continuity and disruption, anecdote and anachronism, subjectivity and objectivity, reason and the problem of saturated phenomena. Active class participation, brief powerpoint presentations and a research project. An art history course is preferred, but not required.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="112">
            Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="113">
            Disciplinary Concentrations
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="174">
            Art and Art History: Art History
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="elective">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="169">
            Art and Art History
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="171">
            Electives: Art History
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="VISAR-AD 176">

         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=VISAR-AD%20176">
          VISAR-AD 176 Foundations of Art History II
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           These courses offer detailed engagements with key works of art -- masterpieces to material culture across a range of media from different times and places -- to develop the critical apparatus of visual analysis. They introduce the methods and fundamental concepts of art history by taking one work of art and constructing around it a web of diverse objects and practices that allow us to grapple with the meanings of art and its histories within global and trans-historical perspectives. Among the questions we ask throughout the course are: What is art? What is art history? What are the institutions that shape the practice and dissemination of art? How is art affected by histories of cultural exchange? What is the nature of tradition? Visits to local museums. Lecture/discussion. Evaluation will be through written assignments, powerpoint presentations, and active class participation. No previous knowledge of art history required. This course fulfills Art and Art History requirements.
          </p>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="VISAR-AD 201">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=VISAR-AD%20201">
          VISAR-AD 201 Interdisciplinary Projects in the Visual Arts
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This class for experienced students is constructed around a series of projects realized in any available media or medium. How the mind constructs pictures from visual data is an extremely complicated set of behaviors that are biological, psychological, social, and cultural. Students are given in-depth exposure to the conditions that are necessary for artworks to “read” and how these conditions have a profound effect on the way people engage with art. This exposure allows students to explore ideas of limits and how the limit or horizon of what is possible can be elaborated and expanded on in art. Students engage in group and one-on-one discussions of projects made in response to readings and assignments whose goal is to foster ideas of exploration and consistency in a creative practice.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2012
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/john-torreano.html">
             John Torreano
            </a>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="VISAR-AD 202">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=VISAR-AD%20202">
          VISAR-AD 202 Form and Space or Concepts in Three-Dimensional Thinking
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This studio course explores materials, concepts and tools used in contemporary sculptural practices. An intensive, hands-on course, it provides a foundation in three-dimensional thinking that enables students to see and conceive of space in a new and critical way. Students move towards self-directed solutions for the creative problems posed by their own art works.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">

         </a>

        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="VISAR-AD 300">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=VISAR-AD%20300">
          VISAR-AD 300 Thinking Art
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course offers engagements with the problems and methods of Art History at an advanced level. It examines in detail works of art that reflect upon tradition, aesthetic experience and art practice in complex ways and does so by situating these examinations in rich historical and theoretical frameworks. The course is open to anyone who has completed either Foundations of Art History I or II and at least one Art History elective but it is designed with Art History juniors especially in mind because the course is, in part, a useful preparation for Capstone work in the senior year. The course is a requirement for all students pursuing the Art History track.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2015
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/reindert-falkenburg.html">
             Reindert Falkenburg
            </a>
            ,
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/shamoon-zamir.html">
             Shamoon Zamir
            </a>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>

          <li class="required">
           <span data-category="2">

           &gt;

           </span>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="VISAR-AD 301">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=VISAR-AD%20301">
          VISAR-AD 301 Advanced Critique and Exhibition Studies
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course is for juniors and aims to prepare them for their Capstone project in visual arts practice through a deepening exploration of their individual work as young artists, and the contextualization of that work through the work of their peers. It is also open to visual arts majors interested in exhibition preparation. The course includes readings in critical discourses such as art history, critical theory, and exhibition criticism, both contemporary and historical, with a focus on advanced level group critique of student work. This course aims to develop a student’s sense of the context of contemporary and historical art practices, and culminates in a student group exhibition in a professional gallery setting.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="required">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="169">
            Art and Art History
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="true" data-id="VISAR-AD 400">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=VISAR-AD%20400">
          VISAR-AD 400 Senior Capstone Research Project
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           The capstone experience provides seniors with the opportunity to work closely with a faculty mentor and to produce a senior thesis project. Projects may range in form from a creative art project to a theoretical or historical research project. The program consists of a capstone seminar, taken in the first semester of the senior year, and a year-long individualized thesis tutorial. During the capstone seminar, students define the parameters of their projects and begin exploratory work and research. The capstone experience culminates in the public presentation of the project. Students may also elect to participate in a College Capstone Project with students majoring in other disciplines in the humanities, the natural and the social sciences. Collaborating students work with a faculty member to define the overall goals of the group Capstone Project, as well as the particular goals of each participant.
          </p>
          <p>
          </p>
          <p>
           *NOTE: As of Fall 2013 Capstone under ARTS-AD 400
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="required">
           <span data-category="2">
            Majors
           </span>
           &gt;
           <span data-category="17">
            Visual Arts
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Prerequisites
          </strong>
         </p>
         <p>
          There are no prerequisites for this course.
         </p>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="true" data-id="VISAR-AD 401">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=VISAR-AD%20401">
          VISAR-AD 401 Senior Capstone Research Project
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           The capstone experience provides seniors with the opportunity to work closely with a faculty mentor and to produce a senior thesis project. Projects may range in form from a creative art project to a theoretical or historical research project. The program consists of a capstone seminar, taken in the first semester of the senior year, and a year-long individualized thesis tutorial. During the capstone seminar, students define the parameters of their projects and begin exploratory work and research. The capstone experience culminates in the public presentation of the project. Students may also elect to participate in a College Capstone Project with students majoring in other disciplines in the humanities, the natural and the social sciences. Collaborating students work with a faculty member to define the overall goals of the group Capstone Project, as well as the particular goals of each participant.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
         </ul>
         <p>
          <strong>
           This course appears in...
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul class="appearances">
          <li class="required">

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="WRIT-AD 110">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=WRIT-AD%20110">
          WRIT-AD 110 Analysis &amp; Expression: Imagi(nation)
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           We tend think of locales as something physical, something experienced. We know where we are (and where we are from) partly because we have physical experiences of those places: a grandmother’s kitchen, a summer cottage, a smell of the ocean, the particular light on Scandinavian summer nights, or the sound of the jungle. Locale is typically the embodied geography of our lives and experiences.  However, what happens when geographies and their relation to identity—national and/or personal—are imagined in cultural products? In this seminar, we will read a variety of fiction and non-fiction texts in order to investigate how space and national and/or personal identity get imagined by the reader and, not least, how the text opens a space for the reader to imagine a world personally unknown.  We will think of the seminar’s foundational texts as being simultaneously in and out of time and space, thereby forcing us to also think about our own lived geographies.
          </p>
          <p>
           We set out by thinking about essays, short stories, and poems that all attempt to capture an experience of self in relation to a locale.  Writers will include Joan Diddion, Richard Blanco, Karen Blixen, Tony Kushner, and Jamaica Kincaid. For the second paper we turn our attention to how the popular genre of crime fiction—from Agatha Christie to Henning Mankell—functions in the construction of imagined geographies. For the third paper, students choose a cultural artifact (poems, plays, monuments, films, memoires, paintings, newspaper articles etc.) and make an argument about the imagining of nation.  Finally, students will produce an oral conference presentation of their research. Theoretical texts include Edward Said, Benedict Anderson, Anthony Kwame Appiah, Judith Butler and Gayatri Chakravorty Spivak.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2014
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            <a class="professor" href="/en/academics/faculty/ken-nielsen.html">
             Ken Nielsen
            </a>
            -

            </span>
            <br/>

            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>

        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="WRIT-AD 111X">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=WRIT-AD%20111X">
          WRIT-AD 111X Analysis and Expression: Contemporary Debates about Islam
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Scarcely a day goes by without some controversy or critical comment about ‘Islam’ -- Muslims -- and its role and significance in the 21st century. Yet trying to make sense of the sheer volume of information and diversity of opinions about what constitutes ‘Islam’, who speaks for it, what it represents for the modern era, and how it relates to the non-Muslim world can—to the unsuspecting observer—seem an almost impossible task. To complicate matters further, what tends to pass as ‘informed’ commentary on ‘Islam’ often turns out to be colored by competing agendas, experiences, and narratives within and beyond the realms of ‘Islam’. With these challenges in mind, this course will revisit some of the key debates about the culture, society, and institutions of Islam, and invite students to form and defend their opinions on a range of controversial issues.
          </p>
          <p>
           <span style="line-height:1.6em">
            A significant feature of the course will be the focus on in-class writing as well as discussions and debate about written and audio-visual media. Over the duration of the semester, students will complete four major assignments: three persuasive essays, all with an extensive drafting process, and a final oral presentation on the subject matter of Essay 3.
           </span>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2012
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            Andrew Patrick
								
								
								
									 -
            <span class="schedule">
             MW, 1:10-2:25
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Fall 2012
           </span>

           <span class="duration">

           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            Andrew Patrick
								
								
								
									 -
            <span class="schedule">

            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>
          <li class="section">

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="WRIT-AD 130">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=WRIT-AD%20130">
          WRIT-AD 130 Analysis and Expression II: The Human Condition
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           Continuing to explore our human experience through written and visual texts, A&amp;E II is a bridge class to the Writing Intensive and Core courses at NYUAD. It builds on the critical reading, thinking and writing skills acquired in Analysis and Expression I, and offers students an opportunity to fine tune those skills in a supportive and challenging environment.
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">

           </span>

       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="WRIT-AD 131X">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=WRIT-AD%20131X">
          WRIT-AD 131X Analysis and Expression II: Contemporary Debates about Islam
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           A&amp;E II is a bridge class to the Writing Intensive and Core courses at NYUAD. It builds on the critical reading, thinking and writing skills acquired in Analysis and Expression I, and offers students an opportunity to fine tune those skills in a supportive and challenging environment. The readings and writings in this section of section of
           <em>
            Analysis and Expression II
           </em>
           focus on debates about Islam. The course satisfies the Islamic Studies requirement. (This course is intended for students who have previously enrolled in Analysis and Expression.)
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">

           </span>

       </li>
       <li class="item" data-capstone="false" data-id="WRIT-AD 210">
        <h3>
         <a class="trigger" href="/en/academics/undergraduate-programs/courses.html?id=WRIT-AD%20210">
          WRIT-AD 210 Advanced Analysis and Expression
         </a>
        </h3>
        <div class="details">
         <div class="description">
          <p>
           This course builds upon the skills from Analysis and Expression and the Writing-Intensive Core courses to prepare students for advanced writing across the curriculum.  The course calls upon students to be creative, critical, and curious, as they rigorously practice their written and spoken expression.  Students engage with a variety of texts and research topics to gain greater self-awareness and confidence with their writing.  Each major assignment is the result of a progression of exercises with an emphasis on drafting and revision strategies. Students work collaboratively, offering constructive critique through class discussion, peer workshops, and one-on-one conferences.
          </p>
          <p>
           Please note: students who have not achieved a pass in the Writing Placement exam, or a pass of 'B' or better in WRIT-AD 110 or WRIT-AD 111X will be dropped from this class prior to the start of the Add/Drop period.
          </p>
          <p>
          </p>
         </div>
         <ul class="sections">
          <li class="section">
           <span class="semester">
            Spring 2013
           </span>
           ;
           <span class="duration">
            14 Weeks
           </span>
           <br/>
           <span class="meeting">
            Kevin Riordan
								
								
								
									 -
            <span class="schedule">
             UW, 11:20am - 12:35pm
            </span>
            <br/>
            Taught in
            <em class="location">
             Abu Dhabi
            </em>
           </span>
          </li>

            Spring 2014

    <aside class="grid_1" role="complementary">
     <article class="component teaser noborder nospace">
      <h2>
       Graduate Opportunities for NYUAD Students
      </h2>
      <a class="readMore" href="/en/academics/graduate-programs.html" rel="nofollow">
      </a>
     </article>
     <article class="component teaser">
      <h2>
       NYU Abu Dhabi Bulletin 2014-15
      </h2>
      <p>
       From degree requirements and course listings to study-away programs and student affairs, you'll find everything you need to know about NYUAD in this downloadable PDF.
       <br>
       </br>
      </p>
      <p>
       <i>
        Please note that this pdf was last edited on
        <br>
         September 9, 2014, this subsequent to the printed edition.
        </br>
       </i>
       <br>
       </br>
      </p>
      <a class="readMore" href="/content/dam/nyuad/departments/academic-programs/documents/bulletin-2014-2015.pdf" rel="nofollow">
      </a>
     </article>
     <figure class="component quote">
      <img alt="Olga Karpova " class="cq-dd-image" src="/content/nyuad/en/content/quotes/student-quotes/_jcr_content/quotes/quoteteaser_4/image.1.jpg/1333283118615.jpg" title="Olga Karpova ">
       <figcaption>
        <q>
         <p>
          In a globalized world, we are constantly faced with situations that don’t have a standard resolution, so we have to be prepared to invent something new, abandon preconceptions, and face the concrete reality.
          <br>
          </br>
         </p>
        </q>
        <small>
         Olga Karpova – NYUAD Student, Dzerzhinsk, Russia/Liepaja Latvia
        </small>
       </figcaption>
      </img>
     </figure>
    </aside>
   </div>

		$("#footerLogo img").supersleight();
		$("div.quote img").supersleight();
		$("button img, a.btnFlatGray img").supersleight();
	}
  </script>
  <script type="text/javascript">
   var _gaq = _gaq || [];
		_gaq.push(['_setAccount', 'UA-11955921-1']);
		_gaq.push(['_trackPageview']);
	
		(function() {
			var ga = document.createElement('script'); ga.type = 'text/javascript'; ga.async = true;
			ga.src = ('https:' == document.location.protocol ? 'https://ssl' : 'http://www') + '.google-analytics.com/ga.js';
			var s = document.getElementsByTagName('script')[0]; s.parentNode.insertBefore(ga, s);
	 	})();
  </script>
